recipient_justification: These expenditures were incurred in accordance with the award terms and conditions for 19NU50CK000510EDEXC5.  As part of the CARES Act and Paycheck Protection Program and Health Care Enhancement Act supplements, the ELC awarded approximately $11 billion in 2020 to help address the domestic response to COVID-19. To provide additional critical support to jurisdictions as they continue to address COVID-19 within their communities, $19.11 billion from the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act of 2021, P.L. 116-260, will be provided to ELC recipients. These additional resources, by law, are intended to “prevent, prepare for, and respond to coronavirus” by supporting testing, case investigation and contact tracing, surveillance, containment, and mitigation. Such activities may include support for workforce, epidemiology, use by employers, elementary and secondary schools, child care facilities, institutions of higher education, long-term care facilities, or in other settings, scale up of testing by public health, academic, commercial, and hospital laboratories, and community-based testing sites, mobile testing units, health care facilities, and other entities engaged in COVID–19 testing, and other activities related to COVID–19 testing, case investigation and contact tracing, surveillance, containment, and mitigation (including interstate compacts or other mutual aid agreements for such purposes).  See 5/01/2025 grant message for an expense category breakdown.

The Immunization funding is crucial for the state of New Mexico as the funds are used for vaccine preventable disease efforts.Under this funding source services from the contracted mobile vaccine team occurred, messaging from the community based organizations, operating supplies, medical supplies, temporary contracted staff for IIS, VFC efforts, marketing campaign for vaccine catch up, to include measles outbreak campaign messaging. 
This funding is from the Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control for Immunization and Vaccines for Children that supports vaccine preventable disease activities through staffing, contractual services, and supplies for maintaining vaccine distribution to all children and underserved adult populations. The Immunization Program has 400 providers enrolled for distribution of vaccine to children and adults statewide to include underserved populations that are uninsured/underinsured and have limited acces to healthcare. It is necessary to provide these services as not adequately immunizing the population in the state may result in breakthrough disease, morbidity, and mortality. By increasing access to immunizations, vaccine preventable diseases will decrease thus reducing the burden on the Health Care system. Immunizations have been shown to positively affect population health outcomes and reduce disease burden.

recipient_justification: Contractor payment to Sage Persuis, Inc.for Immunization Information System operations. The system services cover the Maintenance, Operations and hosting for the Hawaii Immunization Information System (HiSiS). This is in line with the approved activity, in which HDOH established an immunization registry system, enabling collection, monitoring, and reporting on vaccination information statewide and to CDC. This system enhances availability of vaccination data from all healthcare providers and for all State residents. The system increases access for providers on the vaccination status of their patient panels, and empowers individuals to more readily access their own immunization data in a modernized platform. The HiSIS permits monitoring of vaccinations and speeds response to public health events. We certify that these costs are reasonable, necessary, allocable, and otherwise allowable in accordance with the award terms and conditions for award NH23IP922614, awarded in BP2.

recipient_justification: ELC Enhancing Detection Expansion - As part of the CARES Act and Paycheck Protection Program and Health Care Enhancement Act supplements, the ELC awarded approximately $11 billion in 2020 to help address the domestic response to COVID-19. To provide additional critical support to jurisdictions as they continue to address COVID-19 within their communities, $19.11 billion from the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act of 2021, P.L. 116-260, will be provided to ELC recipients. These additional resources, by law, are intended to “prevent, prepare for, and respond to coronavirus” by supporting testing, case investigation and contact tracing, surveillance, containment, and mitigation. Such activities may include support for workforce, epidemiology, use by employers, elementary and secondary schools, child care facilities, institutions of higher education, long-term care facilities, or in other settings, scale up of testing by public health, academic, commercial, and hospital laboratories, and community-based testing sites, mobile testing units, health care facilities, and other entities engaged in COVID–19 testing, and other activities related to COVID–19 testing, case investigation and contact tracing, surveillance, containment, and mitigation (including interstate compacts or other mutual aid agreements for such purposes).  An expense category breakdown for this payment was added to a grant message in Grant Solutions on 5/1/2025.

recipient_justification: The total request is for a generator and the costs associated with it. A generator is critical for the public health laboratory to ensure uninterrupted power for COVID-19 and infectious disease testing, including refrigeration of specimens, continuous operation of diagnostic equipment, and protection of sensitive data systems. This is the only generator serving the entire laboratory; without it, a power outage would halt all laboratory operations, jeopardizing testing, reporting, and surveillance functions. The purchase was included in the originally approved workplan. It directly supports the Enhancing Detection grant’s goal to expand, sustain, and protect laboratory capacity essential for COVID-19 response and future public health emergencies.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
March Invoice:
Personnel: Covers salary cost for the month of March in the amount of $37,614.05 for eight employees. Comp B - Public Health Coordinator (1), Health Education Coordinator (1) and Community Health Educators (4)  and Comp C - Public Health Coordinator (2). Project Coordinator managed and supervised activities and budget for collaboration with local CHWs and partners to ensure the integrity and consistency of engagement throughout project activities. They provided oversight for the two Cohorts of the High School and Young Adult Community Health Worker (HSYACHW) Training Program. Contract Coordinator developed, monitored, and managed four partner contracts and evaluation activities. Ensured fiscal and programmatic compliance with contracted partners. Served as a liaison with CDC program officers, evaluators, and contractors and managed performance measure reporting and invoices.  Health Education Coordinator assessed CHW needs for health education and advanced training; planned, implemented and evaluated Heart Health, Kidney Awareness, and Human Trafficking health education programs and promotions for the training programs; established community partnerships with Berkeley, Dellwood an Ferguson to collaborate on health issues and initiatives; and facilitated the HSYACHW curriculum. Community Health Workers served as liaisons between health department programs (e.g, public health nursing, clinical, behavioral health, healthy homes, corrections medicine) and community social services to facilitate health education and access. CHWs assessed over 64 residents in March, educated clients in individual and group settings, made referrals to address social determinants of health, and integrated CHWS in the clinic setting.
Fringe: Covers fringe cost (Social Security; Medicare Tax; Pension; Health Insurance; Dental/Vision/Life Insurance; Worker's Compensation Insurance) for the month of March in the amount of $15,837.20 for eight employees.
Travel: Paid $3,404.00 in March to include Missouri Community Health Worker Association (CHWAM) conference per diem for Public Health Coordinator, Health Education Coordinator and Community Health Educators; CPR training for Public Health Coordinator and Health Education Coordinator; and Automobile Allowance for County Vehicle use to drive to CHWAM conference.
Supplies:  $11,177.89 covers office an cleaning supplies for Healthy Home Community Education event; Medical Supplies for High School and Young Adult Community Health Worker training program included scales, blood pressure cuff, thermometer, measuring tape; Telephone Service for grant staff (7); Printing handouts for community outreach and Awards & Indemnity for Heart Health, Kidney Awareness and other education event giveaways including healthy eating journals, stress balls, water bottles, and measuring cup.
Contracts:  Covers three partner contracts from September 2024 – March 2025 including Beyond Housing provided client referrals, conducted CHW integration in non-traditional settings, and piloted new CHW-supporting infrastructure ($197,431.32); Saint Louis Integrated Health Network staff collaborated with the CHW Coalition and Health Literacy Media to complete video series - Video #1 focuses on role of CHW; Video #2 focuses on ROI/community health benefit of the CHW workforce and discusses sustainability options. Video #3 focuses on highlighting ways CHW employers can support the workforce.  During NCE IHN was working with Coalition and CHWs to disseminate the videos in addition to trainings to support CHW development. As a part of the CHW Common Data Platform, the IHN built out a searchable database of service providers that CHWs can utilize to make referrals for the health and social needs of their clients. The CHWs can also track the outcome of these referrals.  This referral database and tracking system is being used by 3 teams of CHWs. There are currently 260 health social service providers in the database.  IHN was beginning to work with the UMSL team to see if it is feasible to connect the CHW Common Platform to the database of service providers held by the state’s 211 system. This would allow a more comprehensive set of providers to be accessed by the CHWs. IHN staff was working with the Transition Clinic Network (TCN) to establish 1 or more transition clinics at health clinics in the St. Louis region to serve patients who have recently left jail or prison. This model centers around CHWs being integrated into clinic care teams to provide holistic support to re-entry patients ($385,575.73); and University of Missouri-St. Louis supported the evaluation and data collection for performance measurement reporting. Group Concept Mapping (GCM) evaluation approach was used for the St. Louis Community Health Worker Coalition to develop an Employer Toolkit that includes relevant standards, workforce metrics, best practices, essential resources, a policy agenda, and CHW pathways. UMSL was completing the employer Toolkit Evaluation to assess the Employer toolkit value and relevance to applied practice as well as employer's interest in sustaining this resource long-term. The Employer Survey would have been readministered in April to analyze trends and changes against baseline (after Employer Toolkit Review), and completing the GCM Discussion Guide. They were also helping with the High School and Young Adult Community Health Worker Training Program evaluation ($564,727.35) for total of $1,147,734.40.
Indirect: March $17,987.96

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
1) Grant #: NU2GGH002495
2) Budget Period: 09/30/2024 to 09/29/2025
3) Reason for Payment Request: Salaries & Fringe Benefits for Program Staff
4) Spend Plan: Salaries $465,876, Fringe Benefits $79,199

JUSTIFICATION

The Award is for the Centers of Excellence for Comprehensive Integrated HIV Care and Treatment Services in Malawi under the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). 

Funds are requested to meet the following objectives:
1) To enhance referral-level service delivery through provision of high-quality, integrated HIV prevention, treatment, care, and support services for children, adolescents, adults and prisons
2) To develop model interventions and operations research by piloting, evaluating, and disseminating innovative programs and policies across the continuum of prevention, treatment, care and support for HIV infection and its co-morbidities, both infectious and non-infectious 
3) To strengthen capacity in healthcare for high quality HIV prevention, treatment, care, and support services.

Various employees were engaged to work on different roles to ensure that the above-stated objectives are met. The request covers the salaries and Fringe Benefits (Mandatory e.g Pension) of these employees.
agency_lead_justification: CDC approves the requested drawdown in line with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, Subpart E—Cost Principles, and the HHSA Grants Policy Statement —Allowability of Costs/Activities. Costs expended that are not allowable, allocable, and reasonable will result in disallowed costs and the funds will be recovered.  Salary and Fringe benefits are approved for budget period 9/30/2024 to 9/29/2025.

recipient_justification: Payment is for reimbursement of cost incurred in the current period and authorized to support and complete the objectives of the grant year. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention,
C/O US Embassy,
Lusaka, Zambia.
Attention: Dr Omega Chituwo - The Project Officer
Re: Request to use funds realized from Foreign Exchange gains – Award NU2GGH002484-01-00
With reference to the above subject, we write to request for the use of gains in the amount of $ 529,757.03 (Dollars Five Hundred and Twenty-Nine Thousand Seven Hundred and Fifty Seven and Three only) realized from ADVANCE Project for the period October to March 2025.
The funds will be used to support project beneficiaries based on the planned activities at the DREAMS and Wellness Centers
1. Procurement of supplies for the following program activities,
 School Based HIV Prevention Initiative to support the vulnerable adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) in school and reduce their risk of HIV acquisition. The support includes school supplies to keep the AGYW in school such as Bags, books, pens, Pencils, Shoes and Uniforms.
 Procurement of power backup equipment for the Ciheb offices in Choma and Livingstone, as well as for five DREAMS centers, this is essential to ensure uninterrupted real-time data entry into the program data management system. This will mitigate disruptions caused by electricity outages, thereby enhancing data accuracy, timeliness, and overall program efficiency and Wellness center furniture in the psychosocial counseling rooms to De-medicalize the service delivery rooms.
 Printing of demand generation materials for the wellness centers including viral load literacy tabletop job aids.
 Air conditioners for the wellness centers located in Chirundu, a district known for its high temperatures, a necessity to ensure that sessions are conducted in a comfortable and conducive environment. This will enhance client experience, improve staff productivity, and support the overall effectiveness of wellness services.
 Others supplies such as laptop bags, Social Network Testing Strategy (SNS) incentives and Hygiene packs, Starlink modems for regional offices, and tyres for the fleet of vehicles.
2. Other Direct costs towards the payment will cover,
 Integrated campaigns (Viral load, KYCHS+, HIV case finding and Welcome back to care). Costs to cover allowances for staff and Fuel.
 Trainings for social network testing strategy (SNS) involving 75 wellness center staff, to enhance HIV case identification.
 Meetings for caring for the Carers (Mentors) involving 170 mentors, The Caring
for the Carers meetings aim to support the mental well-being of 170 DREAMS mentors, helping prevent burnout and maintain the quality of psychosocial support provided to beneficiaries. These sessions are crucial for sustaining mentor motivation and ensuring effective program delivery.
 Community Health Workers and professional counselors will conduct an integrated campaign in the first 2 weeks focused on viral load monitoring, KYCHS+, HIV case finding, and welcoming clients back to care at the 18 supported wellness centers. The additional CHWs and professional counselors will also support the sustainability of gains made during the campaigns. This initiative aims to reduce the peer-to-client ratio in service delivery and provide more person-centered care to the targeted population.
 Professional counsellors to provide supervision to Community Health Workers to ensure quality HTS and counselling is provided in the community,
 Local Transport to support community client tracing for index testing, missed appointments and for community viral load sample collection.
To support our request for the use of the gains, we have attached a detailed budget with narratives.
We thank you in advance for your consideration of this request.
Dr. Job Mwanza Clara Silubonde
Principal Investigator Business Official

award_description: GH20-2023 ACHIEVE AND MAINTAIN EPIDEMICS CONTROL THROUGH COMPREHENSIVE HIV/AIDS CONTROL PREVENTION,CARE AND TREATMENT SERVICES IN THE KINSHASA REGION OF THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO - THE KINSHASA SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH (KSPH) AND THE ELIZABETH GLASER PEDIATRIC AIDS FOUNDATION (EGPAF) ARE PLEASED TO PRESENT THE FOLLOWING PROPOSAL FOR ACHIEVING AND MAINTAINING EPIDEMIC CONTROL THROUGH COMPREHENSIVE HIV/AIDS PREVENTION, CARE AND TREATMENT SERVICES IN THE KINSHASA REGION OF THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (DRC) UNDER THE PRESIDENT'S EMERGENCY PLAN FOR AIDS RELIEF (PEPFAR), IN RESPONSE TO THE FUNDING OPPORTUNITY ANNOUNCEMENT CDC-RFA-GH20-2023. THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES BUILD ON KSPH?S MORE THAN 30 YEARS OF EXPERIENCE AND EGPAF?S 18 YEARS OF EXPERIENCE IN IMPLEMENTING COMPREHENSIVE ADULT AND PEDIATRIC HIV CARE AND TREATMENT SERVICES IN DRC. AS PART OF THE UNIVERSITY OF KINSHASA, A LEADER IN HIV CARE AND TREATMENT, KSPH IS PLAYING A KEY ROLE IN SUPPORTING THE DRC MINISTRY OF HEALTH AND LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO ATTAIN HIV EPIDEMIC CONTROL AND SET THE TRAJECTORY TOWARDS THE UNAIDS 95-95-95 ELIMINATION GOALS BY 2030 THROUGH RESEARCH, TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE NATIONAL AIDS CONTROL PROGRAM (PNLS). THIS LOCAL EXPERTISE WILL BE REINFORCED BY EGPAF?S INTERNATIONAL EXPERIENCE IN IMPLEMENTING HIV PROJECTS IN 14 COUNTRIES, INCLUDING DRC, IN COLLABORATION WITH PEPFAR. IN ORDER TO DECREASE HIV/AIDS ASSOCIATED MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY, KSPH AND EGPAF WILL INCREASE POPULATION ACCESS TO COMPREHENSIVE HIV/AIDS AND CONTRIBUTE TO SUCCESSFUL EPIDEMIC CONTROL IN THE KINSHASA REGION OF THE DRC THROUGH CLOSE COORDINATION WITH THE PNLS AND SUPPORTED HEALTH ZONES. KSPH AND EGPAF WILL BUILD ON BEST PRACTICES, LESSONS LEARNED AND PEPFAR/CDC GUIDANCE TO IMPLEMENT THE FOLLOWING STRATEGIES UNDER THIS PROJECT: ?	IMPLEMENT COMPREHENSIVE FACILITY-BASED HIV PREVENTION AND C&T ALONG THE CLINICAL CASCADE FOR THE GENERAL POPULATION, KP, AGYW, INDEX-CASE, AND TB-HIV PATIENTS ?	IMPLEMENT AND SCALE UP EVIDENCE-BASED CLINICAL, LABORATORY, AND COMMUNITY PRACTICES TO PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY PREVENTION, TESTING, AND C&T SERVICES AND IMPROVE CLINICAL CARE FOR HIV/AIDS AND OIS ?	SCALE UP DSDM TO ENSURE STABLE PATIENTS ARE ON ART AND BEING MONITORED ?	PROVIDE MENTORSHIP AND SUPPORTIVE SUPERVISION ON M&E ACTIVITIES TO INFORM PROGRAM PLANNING, IMPROVE DATA QUALITY, AND SERVICE DELIVERY ?	IMPLEMENT OVC ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT THE CLINICAL PROGRAM THROUGH 95-95-95 KSPH AND EGPAF?S PROPOSED PROJECT WILL EMPHASIZE THE USE OF TARGETED, PROVEN APPROACHES TAILORED TO THE SUPPORTED HEALTH ZONE (HZ) CONTEXT ACROSS ALL PROGRAM AREAS. KSPH AND EGPAF WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS TO TARGET TESTING IN HIGH-YIELD SERVICE DELIVERY POINTS AND TO IMPLEMENT EFFECTIVE MODELS OF DIFFERENTIATED SERVICE DELIVERY TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF HIV-INFECTED ADULTS AND CHILDREN WHO ARE IDENTIFIED, INITIATED ON ANTIRETROVIRAL THERAPY, VIRALLY SUPPRESSED, AND RETAINED IN CARE.  IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO SERVICES AND IMPROVE TRACKING AND MANAGEMENT OF PATIENTS? HEALTH WITHIN THE SUPPORTED HEALTH ZONES BY PROVIDING SUPPORT FOR LABORATORY SERVICES AND IMPROVED DATA SYSTEMS AND DATA USE. WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE MOH, PNLS, AND HEALTH ZONE TEAMS, THE PROJECT WILL ENSURE THAT ALL PATIENTS, INCLUDING THOSE HARDEST TO REACH AND THOSE MOST VULNERABLE, RECEIVE THE HIGHEST QUALITY OF CARE.
recipient_justification: To achieve and maintain Epidemics control through comprehensive HIV/AIDS Control Prevention, Care and Treatment Services in the Kinshasa Region of the Democratic Republic of Congo, Our recent payment request for subaccount NU2HGH000084 in PMS will help to provide HIV prevention to 9,138 people at high risk to be infected with HIV, to ensure HIV prevention for the 283 children born to HIV-positive mothers, to contribute to the diagnosis of 300 new HIV infections, to contribute to HIV testing for 2,940 pregnant and breastfeeding women, to provide adequate clinical follow-up of 19,213 PLHIV, and to provide clinical and biological monitoring to 2,007 PLHIV people on ARVs. The total amount of $487,500 is requested for April 2025 and covers theses budget categories of approved expenses: Salaries and Wages ($108,321.60); Contractual ($239,000), and Other Direct Costs ($140,178.40).

recipient_justification: Funds are requested to pay Gainwell contractor for period of April 2025 - August 2025 to maintain Hawaii’s Immunization Information System (IIS), the state’s critical platform for tracking vaccinations. The IIS supports timely immunization reporting, strengthens outbreak response, and ensures accurate vaccine coverage data for public health decision-making. Core funding activities include registry maintenance, system enhancements, interoperability improvements, technical and user support, data quality monitoring, and training and education services. Without sustained funding, the system’s performance would decline, leading to delays in vaccination tracking and gaps in community protection. Continued investment will ensure Hawaii can effectively manage both routine and emergency vaccination efforts. We certify that these costs are reasonable, necessary, allocable, and otherwise allowable in accordance with the award terms and conditions for award NH23IP922614 awarded in BP2.

recipient_justification:
EXPLANATIONS FOR THE DOGE FOR THE DRAWDOWN OF MAY 2025

Major allocations focus on strengthening lab quality systems, data management, and certification support
What the award is for, what the funds will be used for, and why it is necessary
What is the award for?
The award aims to increase access to quality-assured conventional services, including HIV rapid testing, EID, detection of HIV-associated TB, and HIV VL monitoring, in order to attain and sustain optimal coverage and access to the uninterrupted laboratory and diagnostic services necessary for reaching epidemic control and making measurable progress toward UNAIDS 95-95-95.  The award also aims to increase the utilization of Quality Management Systems (QMS) and tools such as External Quality Assessment (EQA), the WHO-AFRO SLIPTA and Strengthening Laboratory Management Toward Accreditation (SLMTA) Programs, Rapid Test Quality Continuous Improvement (RTCQI), and other Continuous Quality Improvement (CQI) activities leading to increased accuracy, reliability, and use of diagnostic test results, which will in turn lead to enhanced uptake for clinical decision-making and improved clinical outcomes for patients with HIV and HIV/AIDS related infections as well as ensure every individual seeking HIV testing in the PEPFAR DRC supported provinces receives an accurate result. A strengthened organizational infrastructure with a qualified laboratory workforce with the expertise to support the HIV continuum of care. 
what the funds will be used for?
The requested funds will be used to implement approaches for the adequate care and treatment of Persons Living with HIV including a novel approach for viral load scale-up. In this regard, our funding request will support the PEPFAR 5x3 strategic pillar approach, highlighting the need to ensure attention and harness resources to effectively close gaps and address inequities, supporting a person-centered and sustainable response following the science through evidence-based and data-driven programming. 
why it is necessary?
The interventions described below in our drawdown request will support accurate, reliable, and timely results, which are important for the effective care and treatment of Persons Living with HIV. The funds requested will support the following interventions:
1.	Purchase of supplies to support Data Synchronization: 
This is a site-level activity aimed at increasing viral load coverage by facilitating the availability of results of EID, IVT/VL through the purchase and installation of hardware and software for the laboratory information system in some health zones Viral Load Sample Management (VLSM) & Viral load Sample Tracking System (VLSTS) currently in use in some sites. The VLSM/VLSTS LIS ensures that once test results are available at reference labs upon testing, these results are automatically uploaded to the VLSM systems and are available for printing in the connected sites for printing and transportation to the sites that initiated the request or to clinicians for client management. VLSM/VLSTS system is active in 18 laboratories, and VLSTS active in 33 hubs. Through this activity, we want to expand the use of VLSM & VLSTS to 29 labs and 45 hubs; this will be achieved by supporting sites with the necessary IT equipment and material to support their use for returning results for patient management. 
2.	SMS result Delivery 
SMS result Delivery is to support the return of high VL/EID results to clinics, especially those with no LIS and remotely situated, to improve retention and Enhanced Adherence Counseling (EAC)  and possibly VL suppression in the long term. This intervention has already contributed to the return of more than 2592 high and unsuppressed VL results in semester 1. The SMS delivery of results also reduces the TAT for results delivery, contributing to better patient management and potentially better treatment outcomes. This model has contributed 46% to the return of high and unsuppressed VL results in the three intervention provinces within the past 6 months. 
3.	QMS training
QMS training: This is to support and guide the Implementation of Quality Management System (QMS) in the molecular and referral laboratories for accreditation and sustained quality services. Implementing ISO,15189 requirements is the ultimate goal of all diagnostics laboratories striving to establish a QMS to ensure the accuracy and reliability of patients’ test results. However, achieving ISO 15189 accreditation is challenging for most African laboratories, including the DR Congo. To facilitate the uptake of laboratory QMS in DR Congo, GHSS is executing this training on the laboratory QMS aspects to promote implementation and ensure its enforcement at all levels of the tiered laboratory network. This is essential for outbreak preparedness, especially in a country that Ebola has plagued in addition to HIV, AIDS, and other epidemics.  The QMS implementation status is evaluated using a pre-established checklist (WHO AFRO SLIPTA) through an audit. Qualified GHSS auditors do the SLIPTA audits.
4.	SLIPTA Audits
SLIPTA audits will verify the compliance of the molecular and referral laboratories performing Early Infant Diagnosis (EID) and Viral load Testing services enrolled in the Stepwise Laboratory Improvement Process Towards Accreditation (SLIPTA) program with the medical requirements for quality and competence (ISO 15189 standards). This will also support the establishment of a national laboratory network to reinforce the strategy to strengthen services and optimize case finding among adult girls, young women, and children, which is in line with the PEPFAR COP 22 recommendations. 
5.	Data Feedback
Inadequate data and monitoring systems and gaps in the implementation of country strategic plans are programmatic gaps in attaining the UNAIDS 95-95-95 target in the DR Congo. Providing data feedback is part of a monitoring and evaluation activity to share feedback reports with sites where data is collected during on-site visits to supported sites, to follow the science behind the data, and to promote the use of data to address programmatic gaps for informed decision-making at the above-site and site levels. 
6.	Certifications
Certification provides confidence in the Point of Care Testing (POCT) results for both the user (site and tester) and the end-user (health care provider and patient). It reduces the operating costs of POCT by getting results right the first time and every time. This activity will involve the evaluation of testers and sites in the 3 supported provinces in and out of a laboratory setting using proficiency testing panels and paper-based tests to ascertain the competency of HIV test providers. The preparation of these certification panels requires supplies which will be procured. 
A certification program facilitates the implementation and maintenance of an effective quality management system; Gives confidence to users in availing the services; Gives confidence to the site and user for the results generated; Provides recognition of technical competence; Helps in defending site while dealing with legal disputes pertaining to results;  Site certification verifies that testing procedures are in place and follow, results are technically valid, only competent staff performs testing, and confirms that the site conforms to a quality management system. -Tester certification verifies that the provider performing POCT is adequately trained, is authorized to do so, and has evidence of demonstrated competency. 
7.	EQA fees 
This cost will be used to purchase and distribute External Quality Assessment (EQA) samples to ensure the accuracy and reliability of laboratory tests. By supporting EQA, we can enhance the overall quality of diagnostics, which is vital for comprehensive patient care. Accurate test results for co-infections and other health issues can lead to better management of HIV patients and their overall health
8.	Waste Disposal:
The requested cost will facilitate safe waste collection, transportation, and high-temperature incineration of used HIV 1/2 Qual Xpert test cartridges for health personnel's and the environment's safety. Guanidium Thiocyanate is the main component of the lysis buffer of the GeneXpert HIV-1 Qual and HIV-VL test cartridge at a volume of 1.4mL and 2ml respectively. More than 538 kg (10760 cartridges) of used test cartridges are in sites in the Lualaba province pending destruction through high-temperature incineration.

recipient_justification:
This funding is from the Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control for Immunization and Vaccines for Children that supports vaccine preventable disease activities through staffing, contractual services, and supplies for maintaining vaccine distribution to all children and underserved adult populations. The Immunization Program has 400 providers enrolled for distribution of vaccine to children and adults statewide to include underserved populations that are uninsured/underinsured and have limited acces to healthcare. It is necessary to provide these services as not adequately immunizing the population in the state may result in breakthrough disease, morbidity, and mortality. By increasing access to immunizations, vaccine preventable diseases will decrease thus reducing the burden on the Health Care system. Immunizations have been shown to positively affect population health outcomes and reduce disease burden.
200 (Personnel + Fringe Benefits)	 -   						
300 (Contractual)	 375,000.00 	Contract deliverable for Immunization Information System					
400 (Other)	 -   						
indirect	 -   						
	 375,000.00 	
The Immunization funding is crucial for the state of New Mexico as the funds are used for vaccine preventable disease efforts. Under this funding source the efforts are for enhancing the Immunization Information System platform that retains vaccine records for up to date modernizations. The deliverable supports the immunization systems by keeping it maintained, upgraded, and developed within HL7 standards and ensures the HL7 is compliant by the standards of an Immunization Information Systems.

recipient_justification:
This funding request is for third quarter activities of the Georgia Colorectal Cancer Coalition to increase colorectal cancer screenings in South Georgia. Funding is for personnel, travel and direct costs for supplies and activities for the months of January – March 2025. Funding is for Georgia CORE as coordinator of the program and for subawardees: Albany Area Primary Health Care, Augusta University, East Georgia Healthcare Center, and Horizons Community Solutions. Program activities for this quarter include:
- Wadley Clinic officially began onsite distribution of Cologuard kits in January. With two clinics now offering kits onsite, this marks a significant step forward in improving access to colorectal cancer screening for our patient populations in Southeast Georgia. Early feedback has been positive, with both staff and patients expressing appreciation for the convenience of same-day test access. This initiative directly supports our program goals of increasing screening rates and reducing barriers to preventive care. 
-CDC Documentation: The evaluation team submitted the spring annual data collection survey for 9 existing clinics and one baseline assessment. The evaluation team updated data collection tools for annual data submission.
-GCRCCP Partnership Evaluation: The evaluation team modified the Wilder Collaborative Factor Inventory to evaluate the standing of our partnership for the future. GCRCCP members completed the questionnaire in December, and results were shared with the team at the Partnership council meeting at the beginning of 2025. The evaluation team led the GCRCCP in hosting the 9th and 10th session as part of the Interactive sessions (for GCRCCP clinics only) and the 24th TeleECHO CRC Screening Project.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification:
The travel costs were for our mobile lab vehicle. This vehicle is charged a monthly fee from our motor pool department. The Supplies entail Reagents and other laboratory supplies for our public health lab. The vendors for our lab supplies are Fisher Scientific, Illumina Inc and Qiagen Inc. 
The Executive Information Systems(vendor) is for "AS statistical software licenses used by our epidemiology team to analyze disease surveillance data. The data is used to inform the WDH on disease trends to help guide public health response, which is approved and in line with the cooperative agreement.
The software maintenance is for our Tableau visualization licenses for the epidemiology team. The vendor for this is Carahsoft Technology Corporation. The software visualizes data for the pubic, informing the public of disease trends and helping them make personal choices to protect themselves. The IT charges are for our epidemiology and laboratory staff to access and use the state IT infrastructure that is necessary to complete their cooperative agreement-related work. We also had telecommunications charges for our epidemiology and laboratory staff to access and use the state telecommunications infrastructure that is necessary to complete their cooperative agreement-related work.
The contractual charges are for Deloitte. Deloitte is part of our continued cooperative agreement-approved work to improve our infectious disease surveillance system. This is being done as a cooperative agreement-related goal to improve timeliness and consistency in infectious disease data collection.
agency_lead_justification: The recipient provided additional details of what is costs entail including names of the contractors and details of the "other" cost

recipient_justification:
Justification for Requested Salary and Fringe Benefit Budget
Requested amount:$ 278,550.00
Under Cooperative Agreement Number GH002402 for the project titled “Strengthening Public Health Response and Accelerating HIV/AIDS Program in the City Administration of Addis Ababa (AACAHB) of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia,” funded by the PEPFAR, we are requesting funding to cover the salary and fringe benefits for project staff for April 2025.
This request is made within the framework of the approved budget for the period of September 30, 2024, to September 29, 2025 (COP 23 Year II). The funds will support employees actively engaged in various health facilities, sub-cities, and the city administration health bureau. The requested amount is exclusively for personnel currently in active roles, excluding any vacant positions.
These staff members make significant contributions across the following program areas:
•	HIV Prevention
•	HIV Case Finding
•	HIV Care and Treatment
•	Laboratory Systems Strengthening
•	Surveys, Surveillance, Research, and Evaluation (SRE)
•	Monitoring and Evaluation
•	IM Program Management

Justification for Stationery Procurement
Requested amount: $21,450.00
We procure and distribute office supplies, including stationery, to health facilities, sub-cities, and the city administration health bureau where our project activities are implemented. These materials are essential for the effective operation of both office and clinical activities, as accurate recording and documentation are critical to our work.
Therefore, we are requesting this amount to cover the costs of office supplies and stationery from the approved COP 23 Year II supplies budget category.

recipient_justification: grant award No.6 NU50CK000553-01-07. Payment to PC Specialist Inc. for Dell APEX cloud based workload backup service for servers. Includes endpoint backup and 5 years support.  This is inline with Advancing electronic data exchange at public health laboratories.  The Dell APEX Backup Services acquisition using COVID funds secures Hawaii State Laboratories’ critical COVID-19 testing and whole genome sequencing data with automated, cloud-native backup and ransomware protection. This eliminates on-premises infrastructure costs while ensuring rapid disaster recovery, compliance, and uninterrupted public health operations. The solution’s unified management reduces IT overhead and safeguards sensitive genomic data, directly supporting pandemic response and long-term public health resilience.

This draw is requesting reimbursement for cost inccured to the State of Nevada, DHHS, Division of Public and Behavorial Helath in support of this project from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. recipient_justification:
Federal Award Project Title: Strengthening Government of Mozambique Capacity to Reach and Sustain Epidemic Control in Zambezia Province in Addition to Strengthening National Health Information Systems

Budget period: September 30, 2024 - September 29, 2025

Reason for Payment Request: Salaries & fringes for the month of April 2025; travel; supplies; service provider invoices. Requested amounts align with line items in the current approved budget.

Detail itemized summary: 
$264,664: Salaries and fringes for the month of April 2025 for personnel that supports the HIV Care and Treatment monitoring system throughout all provinces in Mozambique and personnel who directly provides HIV Care and Treatment services in Zambezia province. The amount includes mandatory employer social security contributions. 
$610: Travel expenses (fuel and lodging) for trips in districts of Zambezia province for the provision of HIV Care and Treatment services. 
$18,236: Servers hosting fees, supplies and internet fees for the national information system that supports the HIV Care and Treatment services, providing clinicians with access to patient information for decision making.

recipient_justification:
Salaries (working on the award and included in the budget) = Epidemiology Coordinator $ 8,100; Administrative Coordinator $6,200; Lab Coordinator $5,700; Project Manager $7,700; Technical Assistant $ 7,560; Technology Coordinator $1,200; Informatic Technician $ 870. Total: $37,330.00
Fringe (working on the award and included in the budget) = Epidemiology Coordinator $ 3,364.87; Administrative Coordinator $2,139.00; Lab Coordinator $2,868.24; Project Manager $3,041.60; Technical Assistant $ 3,181.68; Informatic Technician $ 675.00. Total: $15,270.39
Contractual = Consultants working on the award and included in the budget: Global Health Regional Technician $6,000; Coordinator of Regional Processes $4,300; Global Health National Technician Guatemala $6,000; Regional Coordinator of the Field Epidemiology Training Program (FETP) and Program to Strengthen Public Health Institutes in SICA Member States $ 6,000; Global Health National Technician Costa Rica/Panama $5,400;  Coordinator of the Respiratory Virus Program for El Salvador and One Health actions in the SICA Member States $6,000; Regional Lab Technical Assistant $ 7,500; Laboratory Assistant to strengthen diagnostic and surveillance capacity for norovirus and rotavirus at INCIENSA, Costa Rica $2,500; Emergency Operations Program Coordinator for Guatemala $ 5,000; Coordinator of the Pan-Respiratory Disease Surveillance Program (PRDS) for Guatemala $6,000; Technical Laboratory Analyst for Genomic Surveillance of Influenza and other Respiratory Viruses at the National Influenza Center, in the Directorate of the National Health Laboratory of Guatemala $3,000; Strategic Assistant for the development and implementation of the “DATA MODERNIZATION” project $5,000; Technical Assistance for Strengthening and Supporting Sentinel Surveillance for Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses at the Cobán IRAG Site, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala $1,600. Total: $64,300.00
Supplies = Supplies and reagents to strengthen the diagnosis of infectious diseases, detect and respond to public health emergencies, and monitor priority diseases; for the Central Medical Laboratory (CML) of Belize $ 11,745.00; Box with protective foam, extension handle, and heavy-duty wheels for transporting INCIENSA biosafety cabinet certification equipment $917.40; Supplies and reagents to strengthen surveillance of fungal diseases in eight clinical laboratories in hospitals of the National Health Network of El Salvador and the Public Health Surveillance Laboratory $8,945.23; Laboratory supplies for the diagnosis of fungal diseases for the National Health Laboratory Directorate of Guatemala $ 4,213.13. Total: $25,820.76
Travel (working on the award and included in the budget)= Meeting to Coordinate Activities between Laboratory Teams $995.91; Follow-up visit and coordination of activities at the Central Medical Laboratory in Belize $ 437.88; Follow-up visits and technical assistance, LNV of Honduras $3,483.57; FETP-Frontline-One Health Tutor Workshop Visits, Comayagua, Honduras $1,402.23. Total: $6,319.59
Other = Services for migration and redesign of the INCIENSA institutional website $22,410; Technical service for preventive maintenance of a thermal cycler at the Central Medical Laboratory (CML) in Belize $2,500; Airfare, lodging, and food expenses for participants in the Regional Biosafety and Biosecurity Workshop to Strengthen the Capacities of Public Health Laboratories in Costa Rica $25,575.73; Accommodation and food services for the development of Workshop 2 FETP-Frontline, One Health in Costa Rica $ 10,442.10; Customs clearance fees for supplies $500; International shipment of Candida auris isolates from the Guatemalan National Health Laboratory to CDC-Atlanta $ 2,053.33; Costs of verifying the implementation of POES at Sentinel Sites - Metropolitan Region El Salvador $ 1,000; Simultaneous translation service $750; nternational shipment of a diagnostic validation panel for the Candida Auris PCR test from the CDC in Atlanta to the National Surveillance Laboratory of the National Health Secretariat of Honduras $ 3,850.97. Total: $69,082.13

recipient_justification: Reimbursement for salary, fringe, subcontractor payments, and other allowable direct costs incurred in support of the Louisiana Breast & Cervical Health Program for the month of April 2025.  Funds are necessary to provide high-quality breast and cervical cancer screenings, diagnostics, and patient navigation to eligible individuals. Funds are also used to support core functions including program monitoring, evaluation, data quality and reporting, training, and technical assistance to address clinical concerns. These activities are fully aligned with CDC-objectives to deliver direct screening and navigation services and are in compliance with the Breast and Cervical Cancer Prevention Act of 1990 (Public Law 101-354), and the Breast and Cervical Cancer Prevention and Treatment Act of 2000. All costs are consistent with the approved budget and allowable under 2 CFR Part 200, CDC funding guidelines.

recipient_justification:
SOUTHERN PROVINCE HEALTH OFFICE 
Sustaining the Capacity of Provincial Health Offices (PHO) to Coordinate and Provide Quality, Comprehensive, and Sustainable HIV/AIDS Prevention, Care, and Treatment Services in the Republic of Zambia under PEPFAR.
APPLICATION
Budget _COP23
Funding Mechanism Name:		Southern Province Health Office Zambia 
Prime Partner Name:		Southern Province Health Office (SPHO)
Grant Award Number: NU2GGH002439 
Notice of Funding Opportunity Number:  CDC-RFA-GH22-2206
Budget Period: 2024 to 2025
Reason for Payment Request: Payment for the following:
DD130: Southern Provincial Health Office (SPHO) has an annual target of notifying 5,131 TB cases in FY 2025. However, in the first quarter, the Province managed to notify only 989 TB cases, falling short of the quarterly target of 1,283 cases by 294 cases. This deficit underscores the need for strengthened TB case identification and notification efforts. To address this gap, the Province has planned to send money to the 15 Districts for orientation of healthcare workers in Improved TB screening in Advanced HIV Disease (AHD) and enhanced focused TB contact tracing The oriented healthcare workers will be equipped with essential skills to: • Routinely screen HIV Recipients of Care (ROC) for TB • Conduct TB contact tracing for clients diagnosed with TB • Implement Targeted Universal TB Testing for: o Clients with Advanced HIV Disease (AHD) o Newly diagnosed HIV clients o Clients lost to follow-up o Newly diagnosed paediatric HIV cases Additionally, staff will be oriented on TB index of suspicion strategies to improve on case identification, ensuring that the Province meets its TB notification targets. This training will strengthen the capacity of frontline healthcare workers, allowing them to cascade knowledge to their peers across health facilities. PHO Team will monitor the activity in the fifteen supported Districts and give TSS
DD 130: SPHO supported districts in radio presentations on Male involvement in PMTCT as it is one of effective interventions improving uptake of ANC and PMTCT services among pregnant and breastfeeding (PBFW). The province wishes to continue supporting the districts with the funds that remained from the same activity since Male partners play important role in supporting PBFW especially those on ART. The province hopes to continue improving male involvement in MCH which has been on a lower side and affects initiation of ART when the woman is positive as she would like to seek authority from the partner before starting ART. The program is aimed at closing up knowledge gap in male involvement in MCH among community members. The radio talks will keep on sensitize the community on the importance of male involvement in ANC and early ANC booking (Starting ANC in the first trimester) as well as HIV prevention services. This platform provides an opportunity for health care workers to get views of the community on the PMTCT services since it will be a phoning program as well as clarifying of the myths and miss conception on some of the services provided in MCH.
DD136: The request to print dosing charts for the pediatric Fixed Dose Combination (FDC) of Abacavir, Lamivudine, and Dolutegravir (ABC/3TC/DTG: pALD) is essential to support accurate and standardized HIV treatment for children across health facilities in Southern Province. These charts are critical tools for healthcare providers, enabling them to quickly reference weight-based dosing guidelines and reduce the risk of under- or over-dosing in pediatric patients.
With the transition to DTG-based regimens as per national guidelines, many frontline health workers require clear, user-friendly job aids to ensure proper administration of medication in line with children’s weights and ages. The dosing charts will be used in ART clinics, pediatric wards, and pharmacy dispensing areas, directly supporting correct treatment practices and improving clinical outcomes.
The allocation of funds for printing these charts will contribute to:
• Improved accuracy in pediatric ART dosing
• Reduced medication errors
• Better adherence and viral suppression rates among children
• Strengthened capacity of healthcare workers through visual reference tools
Expected Outcomes
• Increased dosing accuracy, leading to better adherence and viral suppression rates in children.
• Reduced medication errors, minimizing risks of suboptimal treatment or adverse drug effects.
• Improved healthcare worker confidence and efficiency in managing pediatric ART patients.
• Enhanced patient outcomes, contributing to national targets for HIV control and viral load suppression.
• Ensure sustainability – Durable printed materials provide long-term reference tools, minimizing reliance on electronic systems that may not always be accessible.
The investment in these dosing charts is a cost-effective solution to support quality pediatric HIV care in Southern Province health facilities
DD138: This will involve the service and repair of Motorbikes involved in the Viral Load Courier of Samples in Districts. Motorbikes are serviced as per schedule attached in order to continue the provision of services.
DD141: SPHO CoAg receives support from CDC in HIV/TB programming and implementation across the 15 supported districts. The goal is aligned with the National Health Strategic Plan 2021-2026, which states that the goal is to reduce the HIV incidence from 28,000 in 2021 to 15,000 by 2026. The strategies are fashioned from the fast-tracked UNAIDS 95-95. The latest ZamPHIA 2021 shows a national HIV prevalence of 11% among adults aged 15+ years, with Southern Province above the national prevalence at 13.2%. The performance towards the fast-tracked UNAIDS 95- 95-95 benchmarks showed a 89-98-96 performance. SPHO is committed to providing quality PMTCT services in all 15 supported districts. The province is supporting 78 high- and medium-volume selected facilities from the 15 districts with funds for the follow-up of mother-infant pairs (MIP) who miss appointments and for the retesting of HIV PBFW. SPHO supported these facilities in FY Q2. To meet the UNAIDS 95-95-95 strategy, SPHO provides mentorship and targeted TSS activities in the 15 supported districts. This mentorship is crucial in maintaining clinical standards, improving skills, addressing knowledge gaps, and promoting positive attitudes towards patients and work

recipient_justification:
The YMCA of Coastal GA and Healthy Savannah partner to deploy the CDCs REACH initiative. This request for payment is for reimbursement of the grant operational expenses made by the YMCA from January 2025 through March 2025. The YMCA prefunds the grant and does not request funding prior to making purchases. The expenses for this time period included $97,604.81 in wages, $26,517.43 in fringe benefits, $6,730.48 in program supplies, $43,261.99 in contracted consultant services and $20,505.90 in indirect support. 

Wages & Fringe were paid for staff members Joel Smoker, Armand Turner, Ruby Castro Devin Frails, Alyssa Love-Archey, Elsie Smalls and Nichelle Hoskins. Fringe includes health insurance, retirement benefits, FICA taxes, workers compensation premiums, life & disability insurance, and YMCA membership. 

Program supplies were purchased in support of the program from Amazon, Georgia State University, Goodfortune, United States Postal Service, Ad Specialty, Zoom, Inky Brittany LLC, and Claudia Reyes-Garcia. 

Contracts were paid for consultants and services. Contractors during this period were United Way of the Coastal Empire, Carriage Trade & Public Relations, Paula Kreisler Consulting, Next Step Evolution, Think Equity, and Sharon Wyche. 

Indirect Support is the de minis amount provided by the CDC award for the YMCA to administer the grant. Expenses covered are for Accounting, Human Resources, Information & Technology, and Marketing & Communications services, as well as insurance and other overhead items.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification: The requested payment covers one month of operational expenses for infectious disease surveillance in Guatemala and the Central American region. It includes salaries for technical staff, coordinators, nurses, lab personnel, and administrative and financial staff, including benefits. Funds also cover travel for disease surveillance at febrile and respiratory illness sites, maintenance of field surveillance sites (rent, telecommunications), and basic office supplies. Additionally, IT service costs for staff, allocated per project commitments, are included. These funds are crucial for strengthening Guatemala and regional health ministries in controlling infectious diseases with cross-border potential.

recipient_justification: This funding is from the Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control for Immunization and Vaccines for Children that supports vaccine preventable disease activities through staffing, contractual services, and supplies for maintaining vaccine distribution to all children and underserved adult populations. The Immunization Program has 400 providers enrolled for distribution of vaccine to children and adults statewide to include underserved populations that are uninsured/underinsured and have limited acces to healthcare. It is necessary to provide these services as not adequately immunizing the population in the state may result in breakthrough disease, morbidity, and mortality. By increasing access to immunizations, vaccine preventable diseases will decrease thus reducing the burden on the Health Care system. Immunizations have been shown to positively affect population health outcomes and reduce disease burden. 300 (Contractual)149,870.00 MarketingCampaign-Focus

recipient_justification:
The timeframe for this drawdown is 4/12/2025 through 5/8/2025.  The award is for Colon Cancer Screening Project for the Tribal Communities in MI.  i. Purpose: The ITCM CRC Screening Project purpose includes the application of lessons
learned from the multi-component Tribal Colon Cancer Collaborative Model (ITCM 2015-
2020): 1) partnerships with tribal health systems primary care clinics to implement at least 2
evidence based interventions (EBI) from The Community Guide; 2) partnerships with
organizations which provide expertise in implementing EBIs in tribal clinics; 3) conducting an
EBI readiness assessment; 4) Select suitable EBIs; 5) providing for follow up colonoscopies after
a positive or abnormal screening test and 6) collecting high quality clinic –level data including
baseline and annual CRC screening rates.
Funding is necessary to continue screening our tribal communities with the intent to increase screening rates within the health systems.
agency_lead_justification:

recipient_justification:
Re: 21NU58DP007039C3
Budget Period: 08/31/21 – 08/30/25
NOFO Number and Title:  CDC-RFA-DP21-2109 Community Health Workers for COVID Response and Resiliency (Award # NU58DP007039) 

To Whom it May Concern: 

We are submitting a payment request for MD CHW IMPROVING HEALTH & RESILIENCE (21NU58DP007039C3) in the amount of $133,382.34.

All costs being charged to the grant are allowable, allocable, reasonable, necessary, and treated consistently according to all goals and objectives outlined and approved in budgets and work plans.

The budget categories and work plan activities the requested funds were used for are below:

Budget Category: Salary and Fringe for Staff Payments
Amount: $2,428.97
Dates: 04/01/25
Work Plan Activity: Strategy CB1: Training Collaboration - Identify and collaborate with community-wide efforts to ensure comprehensive acquisition of relevant knowledge, roles, and skills by CHWs so they are prepared to successfully engage with existing state and/or local public health-led actions to manage COVID-19 among priority populations within communities.
Strategy CB2: Align Training Opportunities - Align training opportunities for CHWs with the primary actions of state and/or local public health led efforts to address the underlying conditions and/or environments that increase the risk and severity of COVID-19 infections among priority populations within communities.

Budget Category: IDC for Staff Salaries
Amount: $7,874.00
Dates: 03/11/25 – 03/25/25
Work Plan Activity: Strategy CB1: Training Collaboration - Identify and collaborate with community-wide efforts to ensure comprehensive acquisition of relevant knowledge, roles, and skills by CHWs so they are prepared to successfully engage with existing state and/or local public health-led actions to manage COVID-19 among priority populations within communities.
Strategy CB2: Align Training Opportunities - Align training opportunities for CHWs with the primary actions of state and/or local public health led efforts to address the underlying conditions and/or environments that increase the risk and severity of COVID-19 infections among priority populations within communities.

Budget Category: Contractual for Local Health Departments
Amount: $123,079.37
Dates: 03/24/25 – 03/28/25
Work Plan Activity: Strategy CB2: Align Training Opportunities - Align training opportunities for CHWs with the primary actions of state and/or local public health led efforts to address the underlying conditions and/or environments that increase the risk and severity of COVID-19 infections among priority populations within communities.
Strategy CB3: Integrate CHWs (Organization) - Integrate CHWs into organizations and care teams to support the public health response to COVID-19 among priority populations within communities.
Strategy CB5: Promote Engagement - Coordinate and/or promote opportunities, such as messaging/education, within communities and clinical settings to facilitate the engagement of CHWs in addressing the needs of those at highest risk for poor health outcomes, including those resulting from COVID-19.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval
NJ

org_name: Association of Public Health Laboratories, Inc. (THE)

recipient_justification: These expenditures were incurred in accordance with the award terms and conditions for 24NU51CK000362.  The goal of the Epidemiology and Laboratory Capacity for Prevention and Control of Emerging Infectious Diseases (ELC) program is to reduce illness and deaths caused by a wide range of infectious disease threats. The ELC Program provides annual funding, strategic direction and technical assistance to domestic jurisdictions for core capacities in epidemiology, laboratory, and health information technology activities. In addition to strengthening core infectious disease capacities, this cooperative agreement also supports a myriad of specific infectious disease programs.  See 5/01/2025 grant message for an expense category breakdown.

recipient_justification: The Diabetes Prevention and Control Program aims to expand the number of organizations in Nevada implementing evidence-based community behavioral change programs to reduce the risk of diabetes. The program addresses the growing burden of prediabetes and type 2 diabetes across the United States. As part of a national initiative, it fosters partnerships between public and private entities to deliver evidence-based, costeffective strategies for the prevention of diabetes. Nevada used the funds per the approved federal grant budget in full compliance with Grant #NU58DP007368-02. This draw is requesting reimbursement for cost inccured to the State of Nevada, DHHS, Division of Public and Behavorial Helath in support of this project from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Costs include operational, contractual, supplies, other, and indirect through date of 04/23/25. Personnel costs were for salaries and fringe through 03/30/25.

recipient_justification:
Please receive the list of supplies  and equipment on our draw-down request sent directly on email as it is difficult to paste hear. Detailed below are the objectives of the grants and these supplies and Equipment are meant to assist the objective number 4 below.

(1) Optimize workforce management by quantifying Malawi's HRH needs;
(2) Develop a long-term HRH strategic vision;
(3) Increase production and quality of University of Malawi College of Medicine graduates to
provide advanced HIV treatment services;
(4) Domesticate laboratory EQA (External Quality Assessment) systems by taking on
components that are currently sourced outside the country; and
(5) Support the newly established national pharmacovigilance Centers housed at the
University of Malawi College of Medicine pharmacy department in collaboration with
the Malawi Pharmacy Medicines and Poisons Board.

Please note the list of supplies and Equipment has been attached and sent through email.

recipient_justification: This purchase supports software and materials to establish check-in and queue kiosks in local health departments, improving client flow, reducing wait times, and enhancing the overall patient experience for immunization services. While the kiosks will serve all public health programs, they are especially critical during vaccination clinics to support high-volume throughput, minimize crowding, and ensure timely documentation. This investment was included in the approved grant workplan and aligns with the program’s objectives to strengthen infrastructure, improve access, and support efficient delivery of immunization services.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.

$70,131 - Covers salary, fringe benefits, supplies and travel expenses for Surry Friends of Youth Project Coordinator. The Project Coordinator established the coalition for reducing the impact of SUD. Working with the school system to reduce use of alcohol, tobacco, marijuana and (illicit) use of prescription medications for students in grades six through twelve. The period covered in the request is from May 2024 to February 2025. 
$21,728 - C.A.R.E. Consulting provides technical assistance with the DFC program and established the evaluation criterion for the four core measures (1. Past 30-days use; 2. The evaluations started with baselines prior to Surry Friends of Youth project start. The expenses are for the period of February 2024 to February 2025.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.
agency_lead_justification:

org_name: THE CENTER FOR CONSTRUCTION RESEARCH & TRAINING

recipient_justification:
Name of Grantee: 		 Western Provincial Health Office - WPHO 
 NOFO Number: 		 GH22-2206 
 Grant Cooperative Agreement Number: 		 NU2GGH002441 
 Budget Period: 09/30/2024 - 09/29/2025

Reason for payment Request: Travel and Supplies
Spending Plan: Travel:	 $35,580 and Supplies: $55,264 Total $90,845

Travel: $35,580

1.	Support selected districts in conducting mobile ART services to hard-to-reach and flood-cut-off places: $15,980. 
The funds will also be used to conduct mobile ART services in selected districts, as mobile antiretroviral therapy (ART) programs are essential for providing HIV treatment to hard-to-reach areas. The funding will help increase access to care, especially for hard-to-reach places in our rural and underserved communities, which often lack health facilities. Mobile ART units bridge this gap, bringing services directly to those in need. Mobile ART services also will reduce transportation barriers for many patients who may be unable to travel long distances to clinics due to financial, physical, or logistical challenges. Mobile ART reduces the need for travel, ensuring that individuals can receive treatment regularly. In turn, there will be improved retention in care for ROCs who will be provided with ART in their communities and are more likely to maintain their treatment regimen, reducing loss to follow-up and improving long-term health outcomes. Additionally, this service focuses on vulnerable populations, particularly those who are unable to walk to the HF, as they may face stigma and discrimination in healthcare settings due to their condition.

2.	Support WPHO in conducting an assessment of the community HRIS system and HRH site-level assessment: $15,009.
In conducting the activity, WPHO will ensure data accuracy and completeness, which will assist in assessing the iHRIS and HRH sites. This process helps verify the accuracy and completeness of HR data, which is vital for effective workforce planning, deployment, and policymaking. Additionally, the activity will improve how data is used and how decisions are made, helping to find areas where data isn't being used well, which will allow for focused training and system upgrades to support decisions based on evidence at the community and facility levels. Additionally, the activity will strengthen system integration by evaluating site-level implementation, ensuring that the iHRIS seamlessly integrates with other health information systems, thereby promoting interoperability and data sharing. The activity will also ensure that a well-assessed HR system will provide adequate staffing, which enhances service quality, patient outcomes, and community health. Lastly, the assessment will also identify challenges and opportunities, which will elucidate bottlenecks, training needs, and infrastructural gaps, guiding targeted interventions and system enhancements.

3.	Support WPHO to facilitate above-site Technical Support and Supervision and monitoring to the districts  in Infection Prevention and Control in 16 high volume sites $4,591 
The activity will improve IPC quality and compliance by providing focused technical support supervision (TSS), making sure that busy sites follow infection prevention standards, which will lower healthcare-associated infections and make patients safer. This will also provide an opportunity to address priority settings, particularly high-volume sites that are critical points of care with an increased risk of infection transmission. Regular monitoring ensures these sites maintain optimal IPC practices, which is vital for controlling disease spread, especially during outbreaks. Lastly the activity will facilitate the improvement of the Health System The activity will help make the Health System in the province stronger by improving IPC practices through supervision, which enhances the safety of health facilities and ensures they have reliable measures to protect against infections, including new and returning pathogens.

Supplies: $55,264

1.	Procuring stationery for health facilities: $47,171.
Procuring stationery for health facilities is crucial for several reasons, as essential communication, such as paper, pens, envelopes, and forms, is necessary for effective communication within the facility for patient records. It aids in the documentation of patient information, correspondence, and reporting. Patient care documentation, which includes products like patient charts and medical forms, is vital for maintaining accurate patient records on file for ROCs, which ensures continuity of care and helps healthcare providers make informed decisions. All health facilities must comply with various regulations regarding recordkeeping and documentation, making it a regulatory requirement. High-quality stationery guarantees the organization of these records and their compliance with legal standards. Furthermore, operational efficiency, which contributes to consistency, as access to stationery allows health workers to perform their duties without unnecessary delays, improves overall operational efficiency. This work is done in tandem.

2. Support repairs and servicing of project motor vehicles $8,093 
The vehicles used to monitor and supervise activities in the HFs and districts are serviced as needed. Additionally, the vehicles transport samples, commodities, and drugs from the district hubs to the HFs. Frequent servicing will prolong their life span and continuously contribute to the achievement of indicators and project goals.

Costs expended that are not allowable, allocable, and reasonable will result in disallowed costs and the funds will be recovered.

agency_lead_justification: We are requesting additional clarification regarding this drawdown request. An ideal justification includes a description of the purpose and/or use of the requested funds. Ex. Salaries, travel, or contractual payments.  Please review Grant Solutions – Grant Notes for information regarding justification.

recipient_justification:
The timeframe for this drawdown is February 1, 2025 through April 30, 2025. An outline of the charges can be found below. Please reach out if additional information is needed including supporting documentation.

Staffing salaries and fringe benefits for the following roles:
Student Health Services Program Manager - full-time position that leads the planning, design, development, and implementation of program goals and initiatives.
Student Health Services Program Coordinator - full-time position that supports the Program Manager in the planning, design, development, and implementation of program activities.
Office of Research and Evaluation Senior Project Manager - staff member who spends 20% of their time providing day-to-day project management, overseeing surveillance activities, and hiring, training, and supervising survey administrators.
Office of Research and Evaluation Research Assistants - three part-time positions (internally identified as paid interns) who spend 100% of their time implementing surveillance activities under the supervision of the Senior Project Manager.

Supplies
Consumable supplies and materials for professional development and student events
Gift cards used as incentives for YRBS administration
Shipping supplies (boxes, tape) for shipping supplies and resources to schools
Fed Ex fees for shipping supplies and resources to schools
Printing fees for printing materials and resources for staff, students and families

Contracted services
Metis Associates, Inc - conducts programmatic evaluation guidance and support to evaluate program goals and guide future initiatives.
Planned Parenthood - provides professional development and student-level workshop facilitation related to program activities.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.
NJ

recipient_justification:
During the period submitted, the Foundation spent a total of approximately $62,000 on personnel expenses who: 
- Provided design support for patient education material development
- Developed and produced patient education podcasts
- Developed content for web/e-mail outreach and awareness building campaigns, and analysis of campaign performance.
- Project investigator leading the efforts for the entire program. Responsible for management of programs and reporting to CDC.
- Coordinated social media campaigns
- Oversaw the Patient Navigation help center, which offers direct support and education to psoriatic disease patients
- Supported the production of continuing medical education programming.  Supported development of reporting frameworks as required by the NOFO.
- Leads marketing and communications.  Coordinated and managed patient education outreach campaigns and web page development related to project goals
- Manages the marketing and development of project patient audience materials, including copy and production of Advance magazine articles
- Supports outcomes data acquisition and management related to ACCME accredited medical education programs.
- Performed direct outreach and education to individuals with psoriatic disease through our Patient Navigation Help Center
- Assisted with development of continuing medical education podcasts and in-person events
- Performed direct outreach and education to individuals with psoriatic disease through our Patient Navigation Help Center
- Leads development and coordination of ACCME accredited continuing medical education events

The Foundation spent approximately $6,000 in payroll taxes and employee benefit expenses related to these activities. The Foundation spent approximately $5,000 on conferences and travel for attending the American Academy of Dermatology Conference, leading our Collaborative Care program and expenditures associated with our Residents meeting. We spent approximately $459 on our time and effort reporting system and an approximately $850 on printing. Total direct costs amounted to approximately $78,000. We added $7,800, or 10%, to our submission, representing the minimum indirect cost rate. The total costs incurred were $85,000.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval. 
NJ
