recipient_justification: ELC CARES EMERGING ISSUES - Emerging Issues (E) Project funding for adjusting community mitigation in response to COVID-19 As part of the “Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act” or the “CARES Act” of 2020, ELC is awarding a total of nearly $631 million to our recipient base in a program-initiated component funding under the Emerging Issues (E) Project of CK19-1904, henceforth ‘ELC CARES’.  The intention of this funding is to rapidly establish and monitor key activities related to COVID-19 in the areas of epidemiology, laboratory, and informatics.  Monitoring the indicators associated with these activities are intended to assist State, local, and territorial governments in making data-driven policy decisions regarding testing, mitigation, and prevention efforts.  VPD - vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) surveillance  BIDSCOVID -Border Health COVID-19 Surviellance Establish and monitor key activities related to COVID-19 in the areas of epidemiology, laboratory, and informatic
agency_lead_justification: The recipient provided supporting invoices for the requested drawdown to support the requested costs. The invoices have been uploaded into grant notes in the grants management system

recipient_justification:
Program Name:
Southwest Center for Agricultural Health, Injury Prevention, and Education
(CDC Award No. U54OH007541-23-00)

Time Period Covered:
October 1, 2024 – March 31, 2025

This drawdown request seeks reimbursement for program expenses incurred under the approved budget for the period stated above. These include allowable expenditures in the categories of Contractual and Travel, as outlined in the Notice of Award and aligned with the approved activities under NOFO OH22-002. Subcontractor services were procured to support implementation of specific components of the Center’s work plan. These travel activities directly support federal requirements for program coordination and technical implementation as described under “Travel” in the NOA ($19,454 total approved). These expenses were necessary to fulfill core program objectives, including outreach, research implementation, and stakeholder coordination. Subcontractors provide expertise not available in-house, while travel is essential to satisfy CDC expectations for on-site monitoring, community engagement, and programmatic collaboration.

All expenditures are aligned with the approved budget and within the authority of the cooperative agreement. Supporting documentation (e.g., invoices, itineraries, receipts) is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
Award: Strengthening National Health Laboratory Services and Partnerships in Uganda for Quality HIV related Testing and Other Diagnostics through Improved Laboratory Coordination and Management under the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR)

Funds will be used to support the implementation of activities for sample transport, laboratory testing and maintenance of the facility operations to avoid interruption of services. 


Travel category $6,209.33: Fuel to support day to day logistical coordination $5,309.33 and fuel motorbikes $900 to transport VL/EID samples within Kampala and Wakiso districts to the testing labs for the month of May 2025.

Others cost category $70,871.56
Supply of toners $3,372.22 for printing instructions for External Quality Assurance (EQA) panel testing for Health facility testers and results, Health Insurance $185.47, Maintenance and repair of the facility generator $1,109.72, Minor office repairs and replacements at the facility  $920.61, bimonthly servicing of the Integrated National Sample transport vehicles $8,621.12 for 1st to 15th April 2025, Maintenance of the premises and compound (cleaning) $4,375.83 for April 2025, Security of the premises $3,817.30 for April 2025, Facility management $4,000 for April 2025, Internet $3,171 to support communications, dashboards, data capture and information exchange for April 2025, Incinerator maintenance $3,304 for April 2025, Waste management $3,472.22 to ensure the transportation and incineration of the facility waste for April 2025, Maintenance of the Elevator $796.5 that transports commodities, equipment and staff to and fro different levels of the facility for April 2025, Maintenance of the vehicle tracking app $2,945.28 to track the Integrated National Sample transport vehicle fuel usable and movement for April 2025, Fuel for running the backup generators $3,876 for May 2025, Fuel for running the incinerator $3,009.17 for May 2025, Fuel is loaded on fuel cards for ease accountability. Airtime and data $3,677.78 for sample tracking, and coordination of VL/EID activities with health facilities and other stakeholders for May 2025, Procurement of A4 and A5 printed envelops $20,217.33 for transportation of samples from facilities to the testing labs.

recipient_justification: The program is "Drug Free Communities" where our partnership with family connections creates positive mindsets in the county against drug usage. The funds were for July 2024 to March 2025 and this covered payroll for the DFC coordinator and necessary supplies. Her job as the coordinator is to build and maintain the coalition. We meet monthly, in-person. She actively recruit individuals, agencies, and organizations to attend these meetings. All attendees have the opportunity to share information and resources from their agency/organization and flyers for upcoming events. Time is provided after the meeting for individuals to network and connect with others in the room. She also oversee all grant activities which include: awareness events, parent workshops, youth events, and partnership with Early County School System for implementation of Botvin Life Skills Training during the school day.

recipient_justification:
This payment of $75,000.00 to Hilopa'a Family to Family, Inc. for the service period 11/01/2024 to 03/31/2025 is pursuant to Grant Award # NB01PW000057, CDC, Preventive Health Services Block Grant, specifically in accordance with the Healthy People 2030 objective:  Explore quality improvement as a way to increase efficiency and effectiveness in health departments.                                                                                                                                        

Hilopa'a provided facilitation services with the Department team that included the Director of Health, Deputies, Policy Chief, and specific staff to develop a Branch chief summit that provided quality improvement training to increase efficiency and effectiveness in the Department.  The summit trained 50 branch chiefs working with the Director of Health on policy, procedures, and direction for the Department of Health to improve overall services to the public.                  

Hilopa'a has begun developing follow-up training for the Branch Chiefs which has an effect to 300 plus employees of the Department and services the entire state of Hawaii with a population of 1.4 Million residents.   

We certify that the service(s) is allowable and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the NOA.

recipient_justification: This payment supports the salaries and benefits of 37 PRESCA Program personnel, including coordinators, research nurses, epidemiologists, data managers, technicians, laboratory staff, and administrative support, critical to sustaining arboviral disease surveillance, mosquito control, and outbreak response in Puerto Rico a jurisdiction vital to U.S. public health security. Payment dated 03/14/2025 covers payroll, fringe benefits, and monthly life insurance and medical plan contributions for personnel supporting clinical surveillance and patient recruitment, outbreak coordination, community outreach and participant recruitment, vector control operations, data collection and management, and laboratory activities. These efforts help detect, monitor, and prevent the spread of dengue, Zika, chikungunya, and other arboviral threats. Expenditures align with Executive Order 14222 by promoting efficient public health operations and directly advance Executive Orders 14212 and 13045 by strengthening disease prevention, protecting Americans’ health, and safeguarding vulnerable populations, including children.

recipient_justification:
1.	Grant number: 24NU2GGH002554
2.	Budget Period: FY2025 
3.	Recipient name: Programme National de Lutte Contre le Sida (PNLS).
4.	Reason for the Payement Request : This PMS drawdown request supports critical programmatic activities under the CDC Cooperative Agreement by enabling timely site visits, healthcare worker training, and strategic coordination meetings across Kinshasa/Lualaba and Haut Katanga. The requested funds will also support communication and data management for supervision needs, ensuring that critical information is captured, transmitted, and used effectively to inform project decisions. These expenditures are necessary to sustain Strategic Information and Laboratory Quality Management Services to improve the Monitoring and Delivery of HIV/AIDS services in the DRCongo, under PEPFAR.

Salaries : - $ 8 840 
 Travel : - $ 14 344    
Other Direct Cost (ODC) - $44 513.65 Including $ 33 352.50 EQA panel to assess testers' skills at baseline, 6 months and 1 year in 3 provinces

ODC( Bank charges) - $1 354

Total is $69 051.65 – $ 265.61 Cash on hand = The drawdown requested in PMS - $ 68 786.04

recipient_justification: Grant award No.6 NU50CK000553-02-03. The funds were used to replace damaged laboratory cabinets and countertops to ensure compliance with safety standards (e.g., OSHA, CLIA) and maintain efficient COVID-19 and other related existing and emerging disease testing workflows. This expenditure strengthens public health infrastructure by mitigating contamination risks, preventing testing delays caused by deteriorating laboratory cabinets and countertops, and safeguarding staff safety. The period for this contract is June 01, 2023 - October 31, 2024.  The costs are necessary, allocable to the grant’s objectives, and compliant with federal guidelines under 2 CFR Part 200 and CDC requirements for allowable expenses. The upgrades directly support accurate testing and operational continuity, thus Enhancing Laboratory testing and surveillance.  Category for expenditure is Non-Subrecipient Contract: ($64,532.00)

recipient_justification: Grant award No.6 NU50CK000553-01-07  Request payment to Roche Diagnostics Corporation - "The GenMark ePlex Respiratory Panel 12 Test (EA001012) enables simultaneous detection of common viral/bacterial respiratory pathogens (e.g., influenza, SARS-CoV-2, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) through automated, CLIA-compliant PCR workflows. Its multiplex design supports efficient laboratory surveillance by identifying co-infections and emerging threats (e.g., enterovirus D68), aligning with national priorities for rapid pathogen characterization and outbreak response for the period 03/20/2025-10/31/2025.  This is inline with Strengthening laboratory testing and enhancing laboratory surveillance.  We certify that these costs are reasonable, necessary, allocable, and otherwise allowable in accordance with the award terms and conditions for the award.

recipient_justification: This payment supports the salaries and fringe benefits of 37 PRESCA Program personnel, including coordinators, research nurses, epidemiologists, data managers, technicians, laboratory staff, and administrative support, critical to maintaining clinical surveillance, mosquito control operations, and outbreak response in Puerto Ricoa jurisdiction vital to U.S. public health security. Payment dated 03/28/2025 covers payroll and statutory fringe benefits (excluding life insurance and medical plan contributions) for personnel supporting clinical surveillance enrollment, community outreach and participant enrollment, vector control operations, data collection and management, and laboratory support across clinical and community sites. These activities strengthen capacity to detect and mitigate arboviral threats such as dengue, Zika, and chikungunya. The expenditures align with Executive Order (EO) 14222 by promoting cost-efficient public health management and directly advance EOs 14212 and 13045 by strengthening disease prevention, protecting Americans’ health, and safeguarding vulnerable populations, including children.

recipient_justification:
The Drug Free Communities Grant funds 50% of the Executive Directors Salary for the 12 months of the grant. $35,000 is half of the salary for the Executive Director.  The remaining funds come from other sources, we divide it up by the 12 months, at 2,916.67 monthly, we have only taken out funds once for this fiscal cycle, half of the allotted funds, we are asking for reimbursement for the remaining salary, $17,500 of the ED for this fiscal year. This grant also supports the Project Coordinators salary at 75%, the Project Coordinator's salary is $39,000 annually, so DFC pays $29,250 for the annual salary of the PC. We have used $14,625 of the allotted salary reimbursement for the PC, asking for the remaining $14,625 of the salary for the fiscal year. The last piece of salary remaining for these funds is our parttime Secretary, DFC covers 100% of her salary, she is paid $9,250 annually. We have drawn down half the funds for her salary and need to draw down the remaining $4,625.  Of the $62,500 remaining to draw down, $36,750 is for salaries of 3 staff members, leaving $25,750 remaining.

Fringe benefits are listed at 7.65% of the grant for FICA, Retirement is 6%, Insurance is 20.6%, and worker's Compensation is 1%. Cost of each annually through the DFC funds (not including seperate match) FiCA $5,623, Retirement is $4,410, Insurance is $15,141, and workers comp is $735. We have already drawn down half of these costs so $12,954.50 leaving the same amount remaining to draw down.  From the total remaining cost at $25,750 that leaves $12,795.50 left from the funds we are drawing down.

For our travel budget for the year of DFC funds we ask for $2,681 annually, already drawn down half of those funds, leaving $1340.50 left to draw down. From the total remaining above that leaves $11,455 to account for.

Office supplies for the year we ask for DFC to cover $9,900 annually, we have already used $4,950 from the first draw down, the remaining amount is $4,950. From the total previously that leaves $6,505 remaining to account for. 

Contractual request, which is CADCA's annual membership fee $300, Printer Service Fee monthly, Internet costs, Annual Website Domain Fee, and Commonwealth Prevention Alliance's annual Membership fee of $50. the total for contractual costs from this grant is $4,010. We have used $2,005 already and have a remaining $2,005 left for this fiscal year. From the total of $6,605 from above, that leaves $4500 remaining to account for. 

Next is the other category, the first ask is for $500 for a biannual event to enhance youth leadership skills in the community. We have already used $500 from this and are asking for the remaining $500. Teen Advisory Committee meetings (building our Teen Advisory Committee and utilizing youths' voices for community change) we have 4 meetings annually, at $500 per meeting. We have already drawn down $1,000 for this and have a remainining $1000 that we are asking for. That is a total of $1500 left to draw down, from the remaining $4500 that leaves $3000 to account for. 

We support the health of our youth by offering trainings, workshops, and seminars throughout the year and utilize it for at least 5 schools at $500 per school (sometimes more schools if the cost is less than $500, this year it has not been less), that is a total of $2,500. We have already drawn down $1250 to pay for this leaving a remaining draw down of $1250 from the above total we have $1850 to account for on the ask of drawing down funds. We also reduce risk and enhance protection by offering healthy alternative events throughout the year to our youth, we allot $500 per event with a goal of 5 events per fiscal year, which totals $1,250 remaining to draw down. Both of these combined equal $5000 annually, we have drawn down half of these funds already, so we have a remaining $2,500 to draw down. From the above $3000 to account for we are left with $500 to account for. 
The last piece in the other category is Sector Deveolpment where we ask for $1000 annually to provide a report out to our 200+ committee members. We have already drawn down $500 of these funds asking for the remaining $500.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification:
Salaries and Wages:  Personnel are essential for capacity building to reduce obesity. Local and regional staff implement activities at lower costs than state or contract staff. State-level support ensures efficient implementation.

Fringe Benefits: Fringe benefits are necessary per Iowa State University policies for faculty and staff salaries and wages.

Travel: Travel is necessary for staff to work in multiple areas and share expertise. April travel included community assessments, meeting in Ames, a conference in Des Moines, and networking in rural areas.

Materials and Supplies: Funds were used to print walkability audits materials and incentives for community members to share their experiences. This improves infrastructure and gather local perspectives.

Other Direct Costs: Expenses included delivery of walk audit tools, Padlet membership for communication, and subcontracts with counties for local staff supervision.

Indirect Costs: Indirect are necessary for Iowa State University support.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval. 
NJ

recipient_justification:
Notice of Funding Opportunity Number:  CDC-RFA-GH-23-0028
 
Grant Number: NU2GGH002515
Budget Period: 09/30/2024 to 09/29/2025
Reason for Payment Request: This withdrawal is designated to cover expenses associated with specific human resources for work completed in April, the acquisition of supplies (viral load tests), and the payment of part of one instalment for the renovation of the SAE (Specialized Ambulatory Service) in Fortaleza. These expenses align with the approved budget and adhere to the terms and conditions specified in the NOA.
Spend Plan:
Salaries: $ 32,820
The payment for human resources for April, to be paid on May 10th, refers to 81% of the hired personnel, and the activities of this team are directly linked to the following strategies/activities:
 
Strategy 1: Implement highly effective and evidence-based HIV prevention interventions and innovations
Activity 1.1. Expand the information and dissemination of combined prevention in Brazil
Strategy 2: Implement targeted and person-centered HIV testing approaches to reach high-risk populations
Activity 2.1. Increase access for more vulnerable groups to HIV testing through self-testing
Activity 2.2. Index Testing
Activity 2.4. HIV and STI testing and treatment
 
Strategy 3: Offer high-quality, person-centered care and treatment services
Activity 3.1. Rapid ARV Initiation and Linkage to Care
Activity 3.2. Prevention of interruption, lost to follow-up (LTFU), advanced disease, and tuberculosis
Activity 3.3. Virtual Clinic
 
Strategy 4: Promote governance, health system strengthening, strategic information, community leadership, and communication outreach to support project implementation
Activity 4.1: Strengthening the implementation of HIV prevention, diagnosis, and care in primary care services
Activity 4.4: Encourage cross-reference among HIV services and social services
 
 
Supplies: $18,750
Cartridges for rapid viral load Gene Xpert are required to achieve the outcomes from activities 3.1 and 3.2, and for the clients to start ART on the same day of diagnosis or within seven days, and for those who are reengaging in the treatment.
 
Other Category (Service): $ 6,430
This resource is necessary to pay part of the first instalment of the payment (out of a total of 4) for the renewal of the SAE in Fortaleza. Below is the justification for this hiring:
 
There has been a significant increase in demand for the health facility that we support in Fortaleza, called CTA/SAE Emanuel Gomes Pinto. Unfortunately, due to the deactivation of another SAE (Gonzaga Mota), the existing unit is unable to handle all of the demand. This has resulted in a considerable backlog of demand that needs to be addressed urgently.
 
The reason for the deactivation of SAE Gonzaga Mota was that it required a renovation that the municipality could not afford. However, this has led to a worsening of the situation at CTA/SAE Emanuel Gomes Pinto as clients began migrating there. As a result, the service started rejecting clients because it could not meet the demand.
 
Given all this, we decided to support the municipality in renovating the SAE so that the services can be divided between these two units located in different geographical areas within the city.
This hiring is directly linked to activities 1.1; 2.1; 2.2; 3.1; and 3.2.
 
 
Total requested: $58,000
agency_lead_justification:
The payment in the amount of $58,000 is approved.

The Recipient provided the required justification, and this payment aligns with the Recipient's approved budget.

recipient_justification: This payment reimburses salary, fringe benefits, and other allowable direct costs incurred in support of Screen Up Program operations for the month of April 2025, which are funded by the CDC’s Colorectal Cancer Control Program (CRCCP). Funds are necessary to implement core program activities, including the implementation of evidence-based interventions (EBIs) that increase colorectal cancer screening rates in federally qualified health centers in Louisiana.  Funds are used to provide technical assistance and training to clinic employees, support clinics' patient navigation efforts, and facilitate accurate clinic data submissions to reporting agencies. Funds are also used to support internal program functions, including program monitoring, evaluation, and data quality and reporting. These activities are fully aligned with the CDC-CRCCP objective of increasing colorectal cancer screening among individuals aged 45-75 years. All costs are consistent with the approved budget and allowable under 2 CFR Part 200 and CDC-CRCCP funding guidelines.

recipient_justification: Adagio Health Personnel Services Feb 2025, PA Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program  is contracting with Adagio Health to reduce breast and cervical cancer mortality by increasing breast and cervical cancer screening, diagnostic, and patient navigation services to uninsured and underinsured women between the ages of 21 and 64 throughout Pennsylvania. To meet the requirements of the CDC-RFA-DP22-2202 to PA-BCCEDP, Adagio Health shall support the achievement of the ultimate goal to eliminate preventable cancers by maintaining the established statewide network of healthcare providers to provide clinical breast and cervical cancer screening, diagnostic, and patient navigation services to ensure all eligible people get the right screening at the right time for the best outcome.

Name of Grantee:  	 Ciheb Zambia 
 Cooperative Agreement Number: 	 NU2GGH002484-02-00 
 Budget period 	 30 September 2024 to 29 September 2025 
Spend Plan: $53,367.85
1.  Intel Core i7 13th Gen,UHD Graphics,14.0" Full HD(1920 X 1080)IPS,1TB SSD,16GB DDR4 & windows 11 Pro (2 Laptops high specs) $5,250.26	 
2. Cloud Connexa (VPN)	 $17,336.89 
3. BAO hosting T6,WAF,Nessus Scan (Software Development)	 $25,649.12 
4.	Full conferencing for 45 People to conduct Development of Guidelines and SOPs Workshop in Lusaka @K650 per person for 5 days 	 $5,131.58 	
		
 Justification for the IT supplies:

1. Cloud Connexa
We need Cloud Connexa to give our teams and partners secure access to our servers from various locations. It provides strong encryption, centralized user management, and supports modern VPN protocols. This will reduce security risks and make remote access easier to manage.

2. Nessus Firewall
Implementing Nessus Firewall on our servers adds another layer of protection. It allows us to control traffic at the server level, helps stop internal threats, supports deeper traffic inspection, and meets key security standards. This will make our server environment more secure and less vulnerable to attacks.

recipient_justification:
Hawaii Department of Health received a prior confirmation that multi-year maintenance service agreements can be purchased using ELC funds, even when those agreements extend past the cooperative agreement project period but are purchased in full prior to the project end date.

CDC clarified on 8/19/2022 that purchasing goods and services under Federal award, states must follow the same policies and procedures used for procurement of goods and services from non-federal sources (State General Funds), following 45 CFR 75.326. Our ELC Grant Management official confirmed in an email on 8/19/2022 that the following statement is correct: 

“For contract types in which it is usual industry practice to have the payee pay in full at the start of the contract period of performance, including multi-year contracts, the use of ELC funds to pay for the contract in total from the current cooperative agreement budget period is allowed, provided all expenditures are completed before project ends, even if the contracts extend beyond the cooperative agreement budget period.

Multi-year contract types which fit this description include equipment service agreements and electronic software maintenance.”

•	Health Disparities grant award allowed local students to achieve (CHW) Community Health Workers certification.
•	Our efforts to utilize CHW assisted in closing the gaps in care related to vaccine hesitancy.
•	Purchase of materials and promotional items such as hand sanitizer, pens/pencils, T-shirts, and emergency blankets to raise awareness at the back-to-school event and other community events.
•	Travel and training expenses to attend the (APHA) American Public Health Association Annual Meeting and Expo.
In order to better support and address health disparities during future emergencies, strengthen public health infrastructure, and integrate health equity, our collaborations included working with local organizations              
 (University of Memphis, Lemoyne Owen College, Catholic Charities, and St. Augustine Church) and ensuring the health department had the capacity and resources to address inequities and understand and mitigate the impact of social determinants on emergency outcomes.  This includes fostering collaborations between various local organizations, ensuring health departments have the resources and capacity to address inequities, and actively working to understand and mitigate the impact of social determinants of health on emergency outcomes.

recipient_justification: We request a contractor payment to Greater Good Group LLC to support one time purchase of a software license for period 7/1/2024 - 6/30/2025 that automates the conversion of CSV files into Health Level Seven (HL7) messages—the standard public health messaging format used for electronic data exchange. This tool enables standardized data submission from providers who lack the technical capacity to generate HL7 messages directly, particularly those in smaller or resource-limited settings, inclusive of our rural communities. Without it, public health staff must manually enter and reformat data, increasing workload, introducing delays, and raising the risk of data errors or omissions. Maintaining this software license ensures consistent reporting, reduces manual burden, and provides essential support to providers who would otherwise be unable to contribute data in the required format. We certify that these costs are reasonable, necessary, allocable, and allowable in accordance with the NOA.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
SOUTHERN PROVINCE HEALTH OFFICE 
Sustaining the Capacity of Provincial Health Offices (PHO) to Coordinate and Provide Quality, Comprehensive, and Sustainable HIV/AIDS Prevention, Care, and Treatment Services in the Republic of Zambia under PEPFAR.
APPLICATION
Budget _COP23
Funding Mechanism Name:		Southern Province Health Office Zambia 
Prime Partner Name:		Southern Province Health Office (SPHO)
Grant Award Number: NU2GGH002439 
Notice of Funding Opportunity Number:  CDC-RFA-GH22-2206
Budget Period: 2024 to 2025
Reason for Payment Request: Payment for the following:
1. Conduct Comprehensive Pediatric HIV Treatment training for Health care Workers ($27,304) - The Southern Provincial Health Office (SPHO) is seeking funding support to implement capacity-building training for Health Care Workers (HCWs) in Comprehensive Paediatric HIV Treatment. This critical intervention is aimed at equipping frontline HCWs with the essential knowledge and practical skills to deliver life-saving care and treatment services to Children and Adolescents Living with HIV (CALHIV) across the province.
The province is currently experiencing notable gaps across the Paediatric HIV cascade, including:
•	Case finding at 36% (against a target of 50%),
•	Viral load coverage (VLC) at 82% (against a target of 95%).
To close these gaps, the proposed training will cover the full spectrum of Paediatric HIV service delivery, including:
•	Case identification (target: >50%),
•	ART initiation and retention,
•	Viral load coverage and suppression (VLC target: >95%).
The training program will combine theoretical instruction with practical, hands-on experience at established Pediatric Centers of Excellence (PCOE), where HCWs will engage directly with CALHIV and experienced Paediatric HIV specialists. This blended approach is designed to ensure not only the transfer of technical knowledge but also the enhancement of clinical confidence and competencies in managing complex Paediatric HIV cases.
The funding requested will support:
•	Training logistics and coordination,
•	Development and dissemination of training materials,
•	On-site practical’s at PCOE
Expected Outcomes:
•	Increased case finding (>50%) through improved screening and testing,
•	Enhanced ART initiation and retention,
•	Improved viral load coverage (>95%) and suppression rates among CALHIV,
•	Strengthened facility-based Paediatric HIV service delivery across the province.
•	Trained HCWs in Comprehensive Paediatric ART
We appreciate your consideration and support of this initiative, which is vital to sustaining the progress made and achieving epidemic control among children and adolescents in Southern Province.

2.Procure Voluntary Medical Male Circumcision Equipment ($3,614) - Part of the supplies to be procured is for taking vital signs that ensure quality service delivery. The other part is to ensure the safety of clients during delivery service. Therefore, procuring this equipment ensures support for the delivery of high-quality, efficient, and safe services, ultimately contributing to improved public health outcomes and economic benefits. For sustainability of the service even when there will be limited or no external support, investing in this equipment is cardinal

3. External Audit Services ($13,333) – It is a requirement that Financial Statements of an entity are Audited by an External Audit firm.  The Audit firm will be required to issue an Audit Report at the end of the exercise to show whether the Financial Statements of our Organization show a true and Fair view. The biding process for Procurement of Audit Services was done and the successful Audit firm was selected by the Tender Committee. The External Audit will be for the Period 1st October 2023 to 30th September 2024. It is anticipated that the Audit will begin on 5th May and end by 30th May 2025. The Audit firm will be required to issue the Audit Report not later than 30th June to enable us submit to OGS before the required deadline of 30th June 2025.

recipient_justification:
Program Title: Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities, Prevention and Surveillance
Invoice Period 3/22/2025 - 4/25/2025
Summary: Payment for services provided by ORAU to “Leverage Oak Ridge Associated Universities’ Collaborative Strengths on Behalf of CDC’s Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD) National Partner Network (NPN)”. ORAU has provided ongoing contracted services this month as demonstrated by our provision of NPN Communication Bulletins, expanded resource libraries in the NPN Digital Toolkit hosted by ORAU, ready-to-use social media toolkits and materials, media monitoring, an eleven-video series educating healthcare providers about FASD, and communication technical assistance to NPN members. ORAU has contributed to a trajectory of increasing collaboration within the NPN, as demonstrated using a validated scale. The average network collaboration score has increased from 1.88 to 2.35 over the past year. This is a positive move showing that on average the NPN has moved from ‘networking’ to ‘cooperation’ with other members.

recipient_justification: Payment for services provided by ORAU to “Create a Pregnancy and Postpartum Continuing Education Certificate Program for the Peer Recovery Workforce (PRW)”. ORAU has provided ongoing contracted services this month in support of CDC’s requests for us to 1) summarize, develop and disseminate data informed products; 2) build capacity and technical assistance; 3) community engagement and implementation to improve health outcomes for pregnant and postpartum women. This month, ORAU has led a Project Writing Team to draft course content in accordance with the Y1 Content Development Plan and Outline. We are also collecting and analyzing data to establish a baseline using agreed upon data points entered in the Recovery Data Platform by PRW at five recovery community organizations across the U.S. regarding their interactions with pregnant and postpartum participants.

recipient_justification:
Sault Tribe of Chippewa Indians Good Health and Wellness in Indian Country (GHWIC) project aspires to reduce the rates of death and disability from chronic diseases, the prevalence of commercial tobacco use, prediabetes and diabetes, high blood pressure, obesity, oral disease, and other chronic disease risk factors and conditions among our community members.
Sault Tribe is implementing evidence-informed and culturally-adapted chronic disease prevention, management, and control strategies to improve the health of our community members and to prevent chronic diseases and their risk factors.
Our approach includes:
1. Providing a foundation for chronic disease prevention by implementing community-chosen, traditional practices that build resilience and strengthen connections to family, culture, and community.
2. Establishing and enhancing systems that connect community members to community, clinical, and social services and programs to prevent, manage, and control chronic diseases and their risk factors.
3. Promoting the implementation of multi-disciplinary team-based care to prevent, manage, and control chronic diseases and to connect patients to community and social service providers to address health-related social and economic needs.

recipient_justification:
The requested amount is to reimburse costs related to implementation of the PREVAYL grant in accordance with Linn County's year 4 workplan, budget, and implementation plans to address youth violence. The following breakdown is what was charged

Salary/Fringe: $8,766.32
Other: $800
Contract: $23,363.85
Indirect: $2,200

Total: $35,130.17


Salary/Fringe of Linn County employees: 
Salary = $6,518.45; Fringe: $2,247.87; for a total of 162 hours spent implementing the workplan, evaluation, and reporting requirements [(project director) 46 hrs @ $68.74 = $3,161.93; (SDoH Epidemiologist) 22 hrs @$52.53 = $1,155.66; (Program Planner working at the Juvenile Detention Center) 11.5 hrs @ $45.99 = $528.89; (Senior Health Education Specialist) 33.5 hrs @ $44.75 = $1,499.13; (Evaluation Lead) 41 hrs @$47.84 = $1,961.44; (Care Coordination Lead) 8 hrs @ $57.41 = $459.28]

Two events were held by the Stand Up for Peace collaborative, the first "Stop the Violence Event" on 3/29/2025 and second the Youth Empowerment Summit (5/3/2025) in relation to Goal 1 and 2 of the PREVAYL NOFO. Both events were located in the Linn County Public Health gym, which required floor covering to be laid to protect the gym floor at a cost of $400 each time with the following breakdown:

2 employees load floor materials at Obrien and deliver to Harris - 30 minutes = 1 hour 

4 employees to install floor covering - 1 hour = 4 hours  

Tape seams - 4 rolls at $25 each = $100 

1 employee clean floor 1 hour 

4 employees to pick up floor covering - 1 hour = 4 hours 

2 employees load and return to Obrien - 30 minutes = 1 hour 

 

Floor covering cost 10 hour @$30(estimated) = $300 

Tape $100 

 
$400 Linn County Costs for floor covering 

Contract labor related to implementation of the Group Violence Intervention Strategy was charged by contractor, Foundation 2 Crisis Services, for three months of work in 2025 to include:

January: $6987.95 (Salaries/Fringe: 173.33 hr at $29.02, 45.07 hr at $38.74, 1.73 hr at $76.13; Other: Cellphone/Data Plan $40, iPad data plan $40)
February: $9,387.95 (Salaries/Fringe: 173.33 hr at $29.02, 45.07 hr at $38.74, 1.73 hr at $76.13; Other: Cellphone/Data Plan $40, iPad data plan $40, Gift cards: $2400 as incentives and to address barriers to transportation and clothing to obtain employment)
March: $6987.95 (Salaries/Fringe: 173.33 hr at $29.02, 45.07 hr at $38.74, 1.73 hr at $76.13; Other: Cellphone/Data Plan $40, iPad data plan $40)

$2,200 was charged for rental space related to our skill building workshops and addressing barriers related to reliable transportation: Chain Reaction Bike Hub

recipient_justification:
Drawdown Summary Request 

1. Other—$35,006.37: Funds will be used to support the in-service training of HIV nurse practitioners (HNPs) as they attain skills in the management of HIV ROCs. HNP training will improve patient outcomes, and investments in training HNPs enhance their clinical skills and knowledge, leading to better patient care and improved health outcomes for individuals living with HIV. The HNP training will also address workforce shortages. Considering the growing demand for HIV management, enhancing the skill set of existing HNPs helps address potential shortages and ensures a competent workforce is available to meet patient needs. Training HNPs will also be cost-effective, as it reduces long-term healthcare costs by preventing complications and hospitalizations through better management and early intervention in HIV-related health issues. WPHO will also use the funds to conduct above-site monitoring of already trained HNPs in the districts. The monitoring will also facilitate feedback and improvement, as it provides an opportunity for HNPs to receive feedback on their performance, identify areas for improvement, and allow targeted support or refresher training as needed to enhance their skills. There will also be enhanced accountability as regular monitoring fosters accountability among HNPs, encouraging them to adhere to established protocols and guidelines in HIV management, which can lead to improved health outcomes for patients. The process will also assist in identifying training gaps for future consideration, as this above-site monitoring can identify specific areas where HNPs may require additional training or resources, ensuring that ongoing education is aligned with the challenges they face in practice.

recipient_justification:
NOFO: Comprehensive High-Impact HIV Prevention Programs for Community-Based Organizations
Grant #: 21NU62PS924707
Budget Period: 7/1/2024-6/30/2025

The High Impact Prevention Program (HIPP) is a public health initiative that offers education, STI screening and testing, and connects people to primary health care. Louisiana State Certified HIV counselors run the program and work closely with the community by partnering with colleges, social organizations, churches, and treatment centers. These counselors identify individual needs and help people access primary care as well as support services like behavioral health and case management. HIPP also reaches the community through its Instagram page, which shares information about healthy habits.

The reimbursement request covers expenses from March 1, 2025, to March 31, 2025. Expenses include salaries of $17,614, benefits totaling $4,400, and shared operational costs. These shared costs are: business insurance at $3,120, utilities at $616, telephone and internet at $250, office supplies at $800, OSHA-related expenses at $3,200, and audit costs at $5,000.

The Westmoreland County Youth Summit was held on February 4, 2025.  Student representatives as well as school administrators/teachers, from all 17 public schools and other private schools in the county, were invited.  Fifteen schools were in attendance.  This Youth Summit provided a forum for young people to organize, network, utilize PAYS data and share their hopes and concerns in a public setting. The summit is an excellent opportunity to build the developmental assets of young participants by learning more about what they experience in the places they spend time and provide the students with knowledge to make positive change. The goal of the summit was to encourage peer-to-peer education by the students at their home schools. The students and advisors left the summit with a plan to conduct an activity or event to educate their peers. Mini grants, through other funding sources, were offered to each school to implement peer-to-peer education surrounding underage drinking at their school.

recipient_justification:
The request is for the timeframe January 1, 2025 - March 31, 2025.

Payroll Reimbursement: Salary and benefits ($26,705.34) for one staff person providing Youth Substance Use Prevention. Deschutes County youth drug use rates are higher than Oregon State averages, strongly correlated with poor academic and health outcomes. As highlighted in our August 2024 Progress Report, Deschutes County is a vibrant vacation community with heavy economic reliance on Alcohol and Marijuana small businesses and the business sponsorship of community events targeting families. The social acceptance of Alcohol and Marijuana, ease of community availability, and mixed messages to youth about substance use create a risk factor for our youth that the Drug Free Communities (DFC) Coordinator is actively working to mitigate using universal prevention strategies in the following ways:
•	Collaboration with local small businesses, event coordinators, and ODOT to provide information, education, and alternatives in Community Event Spaces where youth are present 
•	Partnership with 2 local colleges on summer safety topics for students, focused on topics like: Narcan and fentanyl test strip trainings, binge drinking education, impaired driving recognition and alternatives
•	Participation in K-12 and college health fairs and parent nights to distribute important safety information

Education & Travel Expenses: Airfare ($669.27 on purchase card), lodging expenses ($2,567.77), and conference registration ($1,490) for two Drug Free Communities (DFC) coalition members and the DFC Coordinator to the 2025 National CADCA Leadership Forum*. The coordination and existence of a community coalition are required activities per the CDC/ONDCP DFC grant. A protective factor outlined in our 2024 Progress Report is focused on the power and quality of the parent-child connection and its impact on overall health but specifically substance use initiation. The coalition members attended sessions to educate them on the facilitation of and enhancement of programs providing support and education to increase parents’ efficacy when having difficult conversations with their kids. This education is necessary for our coalition to deliver quality and up to date programming for parents, inform our social norm media campaign on how to ‘Start the Conversation’ with their youth, and continue to support the school district in management of youth who may be initiating use of substances.

Print Materials: A core activity of our award is increasing access to treatment and services. Printing expenses were incurred during this timeframe in order to share information about treatment and services in collaboration with the school district for impacted youth at two of the CADCA Conference breakout sessions. Business cards ($53.50) were also printed for the DFC Coordinator who serves as the grant project coordinator and was new to the role April 2024 and needs to provide contact information to counterparts. 

Indirect: Deschutes County elects to claim de minimis (10% at time of NOA) = $3,148.59

Total request = $34,634.47



*The 2025 National CADCA Leadership Forum occurred during February in Washington D.C.  CADCA stands for Community Anti-Drug Coalitions of America.

recipient_justification:
The comprehensive outline below provides a breakdown of all line items on our invoice to ensure clarity and alignment with your records.

$12,612.64 - Salaries and Wages 
Project Coordinator (Sher Rowley) provides critical leadership to ensure that project activities are implemented with fidelity to the approved strategic plan. Her responsibilities include coordinating coalition efforts, overseeing program implementation, managing timelines, and ensuring grant objectives are met. Her consistent engagement helps maintain alignment with federal program expectations and ensures accountability across all activities.

Business Official (Gina DeSantis) plays a vital operational role by overseeing administrative and financial processes related to the grant. She ensures compliance with budgetary requirements, manages financial reporting, and supports the timely execution of project expenditures. Her oversight is instrumental in keeping the project on track and ensuring that all fiscal responsibilities are met efficiently.
Both staff members' expertise and commitment are essential to the project's integrity, efficiency, and success. 

$6,534.52 - Fringe Benefits: 
Fringe benefits include Vision, Dental, Retirement, Health, Medicare, HSA, Life Insurance, and Workers Compensation.

These line items support the contributions of two key personnel essential to successfully implementing and overseeing the grant project: the DFC Project Coordinator and the Business Official.

$4,298.76—Training & Travel: This line item supports the local and out-of-state travel necessary to implement and oversee the DFC grant project effectively.

Local travel includes mileage reimbursement for the project coordinator and assistant coordinator to attend meetings, site visits, and community events directly related to executing the DFC action plan. These activities are essential for maintaining coalition engagement, supporting local prevention strategies, and ensuring project fidelity.

Out-of-state travel covers attendance at the CADCA National Leadership Forum, a premier training event focused on substance use prevention. Participation in this forum allows staff to gain up-to-date knowledge, access national best practices, and strengthen professional networks, which enhances the quality and impact of local programming.

In-state travel includes attendance at the Utah Prevention Coalition Association (UPCA) training in Bryce Canyon. This training provides state-specific guidance, resources, and professional development tailored to prevention professionals working within Utah.

Participation in these events ensures that personnel are equipped with the most current research, skills, and tools in prevention science, which directly supports the goals and sustainability of the DFC project.

USBE Training - This line item supports travel for five (5) coalition members to attend the Utah State Board of Education (USBE) Prevention Training held in Bryce Canyon, Utah. Our CDC point of contact approved this opportunity as a reallocation of previously designated funds for the Montana Institute due to scheduling conflicts that prevent coalition members and coordinators from attending the Montana event. The content provided by the Montana Institute will be delivered at the Bryce Canyon training, ensuring no loss in educational value. Attending this training enables coalition members to receive essential professional development in prevention science, expand their knowledge of effective strategies, and strengthen coalition efforts. This investment aligns with our goals for capacity building, sustainability, and community impact.
Mileage reimbursement for Julie Anderson, a dedicated and long-standing volunteer with the Weber Communities That Care (CTC) coalition, to attend the Prevention Specialist Training at the Willow Creek Inn in Ephraim, Utah. Julie’s participation in this training was approved by the Executive Committee as part of the coalition’s commitment to capacity building, member development, and volunteer recognition. Upon completion, Julie will be eligible to become a Certified Prevention Specialist, significantly enhancing her ability to contribute to the coalition’s efforts. Julie is a core Guiding Good Choices program facilitator and a passionate advocate for policy change and substance use prevention. Equipping her with additional tools and training strengthens her impact. It benefits the coalition by enhancing our capacity to drive environmental strategies, advocate for policy-level change, and engage the community through an informed and empowered champion.
Uber rides for two adult advisors and six youth coalition members during their participation in the CADCA National Leadership Forum in Washington, D.C.

Transportation was necessary to facilitate site visits to Arlington National Cemetery, to provide historical and civic context as part of leadership development. The International Spy Museum – to enhance youth engagement through interactive learning on national security and decision-making. Capitol Hill – to meet directly with elected representatives, allowing youth to practice advocacy skills and present their substance use prevention efforts nationally.

These activities aligned with CADCA’s focus on civic engagement, leadership, and policy awareness, and supported youth in applying prevention strategies in real-world contexts. Transportation ensured safety, accessibility, and efficient movement between training sessions and educational visits.

$1031.45 - Supplies: Essential supplies, postage, and printing costs (going towards paper, toner, ink) for the DFC grant project. These supplies are critical to the functioning, reach, communications, and outputs of the DFC project and include printing and production of fliers, meeting and training materials, and overall grant documentation and tracking. 

Appreciation gift of flowers to the presenters of the Executive Committee training on the Social Development Strategy. Providing a small token of appreciation acknowledges the time and expertise presenters share and supports a positive, respectful coalition culture. Recognizing contributions in this way helps reinforce volunteer engagement and strengthens relationships with key stakeholders.

Event and Outreach Equipment: A 10x10 canopy was purchased for use at outdoor community events to increase coalition visibility and provide shelter for staff and materials. Additional items such as storage bins and a label maker support organized, functional use and transport of coalition merchandise and materials.

Technology Protection: An Owl case was purchased to protect the Owl video conferencing device during frequent transportation, preventing damage and reducing the risk of needing a costly replacement.

Meeting and Program Supplies: Ongoing materials are needed for coalition meetings, work group sessions, and Guiding Good Choices (GGC) parenting classes. These include bottled water, plates, utensils, and food boxes to manage refreshments and accommodate leftovers for attendees, which supports participation and engagement, particularly for families attending evening sessions.

Printing and Educational Materials: Funds also support the printing of: Social Development Strategy (SDS) handouts for teacher training and youth application at CADCA events, CADCA Youth awards for students presenting their elevator speeches to legislators, and Infographics on the Social Development Strategy distributed to educators during Read Across America school events.

These supplies are critical for effective coalition operations, promoting awareness, encouraging participation, and ensuring high-quality implementation of program strategies and community outreach efforts.

$6,000.00 - Contractual costs: Evaluation Contract and Consultation with Bach Harrison, LLC to guarantee maintenance with Core Reporting requirements of the DFC grant project. This includes collecting and inputting core measures, creating an evaluation report, providing coalition evaluation support, providing activity evaluation support (e.g., strategy measures, focus group development), and conducting coalition member surveys (youth and adult). Includes monthly meetings to review the action plan and assessment protocols and discuss future data collection and evaluation needs.

$706.71 - Other expenses: Other expenses include payroll processing fees, cell phone allowances for the project coordinator and assistant coordinator, and annual membership dues to CADCA*. 

*CADCA stands for Community Anti-Drug Coalitions of America. It's a prominent non-profit organization focused on substance use prevention, representing a network of community coalitions working to build safe and healthy communities. CADCA's mission is to strengthen the capacity of community coalitions to create and maintain safe, healthy, and drug-free communities globally.

$3,118.41 - Indirect costs: Charged at the federally approved de minimis rate of 10%, these funds cover the essential and reasonable administrative costs associated with maintaining the organization’s infrastructure and other basic operational functioning supporting this grant project's management and oversight.

recipient_justification:
This award supports the development of an advanced PPE system for healthcare workers, including self-decontaminating isolation gowns and respirators, to enhance protection against infectious diseases and reduce occupational exposure risks.
 
Funds will be used to develop biocidal textile materials, fabricate and test protective gowns and respirators, conduct ergonomic and performance evaluations, and collaborate with manufacturers for prototyping and potential commercialization.
 
Current PPE is inadequate in fit, comfort, and contamination control, contributing to high infection rates among healthcare workers. This project addresses critical gaps by delivering reusable, user-friendly, and biocidal PPE solutions aligned with NIOSH’s goals to reduce workplace risks of injuries and disease.
 
Salary/wages = 7974.37 and fringe benefits = 917.68 for PI/COPI and graduate students in accordance with award terms and conditions for conducting planed research activities. 

Honoraria/service = 112.90 for fee for service testing in accordance with award terms and conditions.

Subcontracts = 19938.42 for conducting research activities at UC Davis and University of Cincinnati sites in accordance with award terms and conditions.

Facilities and administration = 4772.60 for indirect costs associated with research activities in accordance with award terms and conditions.

recipient_justification:
Budget period is 09/30/24 - 09/29/25

The payment request will cover activities incurred in relation to the Birth Defects surveillance project for the month of April 2025 under the award NU2GGH002359.

The spending plan of $33,599 is broken down as follows:
- Salaries and fringe: $29,700
This cover staff costs and equivalent fringe benefits of staff engaged in the project. The monthly accumulated FTE is 29. The staff include the  PI, Program Manager, Data, Hospital Coordinator, Midwives, Research Assistants etc.
- Communication cost: $50
This cover airtime costs utilized by project team in routine communication
- Supplies: $200
This cover procurement of routing project supplies like toner, photocopying papers including hospital supplies like gloves, gowns etc
- Consultant charges: $1,000
This cover the quarter-end payments for 4 hospital consultants engaged in assisting with review and confirmation of any birth defects identified during surveillance activities
- Domestic travel charges including fuel and vehicle repairs: $150
This cover the scheduled local trips of supervision & monitoring team between various hospital sites where the project is conducted, including cost of fuel and repairs
- Bank charges: $10
This cover the monthly ledger fees paid for the dedicated project bank accounts - both in USD and local currency
- Indirect Costs: $2,489
This represents an 8% indirect cost rate allowable for foreign institution

org_name: NATIONAL BIRTH DEFECTS PREVENTION NETWORK INC.

recipient_justification:
This award supports the development of scientifically engineered protective gloves specifically designed for fishery workers, addressing high rates of hand injuries caused by cold, wet conditions, ergonomic strain, and inadequate current glove designs.
 
Funds will be used to conduct focus group interviews, evaluate existing glove materials, perform advanced 3D scanning and thermal testing, develop a 3D multi-segment hand thermoregulation model, and run human trials in controlled environments to assess how glove properties, posture, and environment affect blood flow, dexterity, and injury risk.
 
Fishery workers experience disproportionately high rates of hand injuries due to extreme working conditions and poor glove performance. This project will generate critical data, predictive tools, and design guidelines that directly support safer, more functional PPE, in alignment with the NIOSH's goal to reduce the risks of workplace injuries and diseases.
Salary/wages = 17315.09 and fringe benefits = 3741.02 for PI/COPI and graduate students in accordance with award terms and conditions for conducting planed research activities. 

Student tuition = 839.31 for graduate students in accordance with award terms and conditions and Iowa State University student tuition policies.

Supplies = 20.53 for conducting research activities in accordance with award terms and conditions.

Facilities and administration = 11170.63 for indirect costs associated with research activities in accordance with award terms and conditions.

recipient_justification: With current funding, NAFC advanced efforts to support women 35+ with incontinence. We analyzed over 2,700 survey responses and finalized Draft 1 of the National Indicator Report, incorporating 78+ resources. Our point-of-care campaign reached 162,430 patients, with 1,500+ requesting a follow-up guide. A follow-up and control survey assessed campaign impact; younger women (35–44) showed the most notable lift in screening intent. We launched a new Life Without Leaks podcast episode, developed a Grand Rounds webinar (launching May), and earned 54,147 banner ad impressions. Social campaigns reached 102,000+ patients and 112,000 HCPs, generating over 1,000+ clicks. We also created 1 new fact sheet and 2 tools for future launch, and sent April emails to 8,254 patients and 2,759 HCPs. Bi-weekly calls and submission of the Annual Performance Report completed the month’s work.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification: Salary & fringe was charged for the 2 principal investigators and 4 co-investigators on this component, to support their time overseeing & guiding recruitment, enrollment, & specimen collecting and processing. Laboratory staff were involved in collecting, processing and testing the clinical specimens obtained from the surveillance project. Biostatistician was involved in data recovery from health information system and research redcap database, data analysis and preparation of study reports for publication. Medical supplies were used for clinical specimen collection, saving and testing. There were reagents used for nucleic acid amplification of viruses from clinical samples. Barcode scanners were also purchased to track everything. Indirect expenses were charged on salary, fringe, & medical supplies at the agreed upon rate of 33%.

recipient_justification: Grant award No.1 NU58DP007762-01-00 - Request payment to OmniTrak Group, Inc for contractual  services provided in April 2025 for continued support in collection for the Hawaii Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) for the service period from January 1, 2025, to June 29, 2025. The BRFSS is a critical public health surveillance initiative overseen by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Activities include the administration of CDC core questions, optional modules, and state-added items to capture timely, population-based data on health behaviors, chronic conditions, and preventive health practices among Hawaii residents. These data are essential for informing public health policy, program planning, and meeting federal reporting requirements. Ensuring timely and accurate data collection maintains the quality and integrity of the BRFSS dataset, which underpins evidence-based decision-making at the state, local, and national levels.

recipient_justification:
The recent announcement of the Foreign Aid freeze by the U.S. Government and subsequent work stop-order by Implementing Partners supported by PEPFAR (USAID and CDC) had resulted in the abrupt disruption of HIV service delivery in many facilities. Consequently, the Ministry of Health had promptly put in measures for continuity of HIV services including by redesigning HIV service provision through the revised minimum HIV service package to ensure that HIV services adhere to the PEPFAR waiver and are sustainable. Despite measures put in place, there are still reports of gaps in the commodity stock levels and challenges in the provision of HIV services both at community and facilities levels. This is more pronounced in the northern half of the country where we have had termination of some of the USAID partners and those that are resuming their activities are yet to operate at full scale.  Given the above situation, there is an urgent need for the National HIV Program team to conduct onsite checks and offer technical support to the various facilities across the country.  

The program is therefore, requesting to draw the approved and concurred with funds totaling US$27,489.40 (Twenty-Seven Thousand Four Hundred Eighty-Nine Dollars Forty Cents Only) from the Year 5 MoH/CDC CoAg Treatment Budget Line under the onsite assessment for continuity of HIV services provision and support supervision. These funds will support program and technical officers with travel expenses which include fuel and per diem (daily subsistence allowance) as per approved government rates. These funds will enable the central level teams comprising Clinical, Pharmacy, Laboratory and Strategic Information Personnel travel to all the provinces, selected districts and facilities (Urban, Peri-Urban and Rural). The activity will focus on determining the commodity stock status, HIV service delivery, and provide onsite guidance on continuity of HIV services as per PEPFAR waiver on life-saving activities as well as the Ministry revised minimum HIV service package. This is also aimed at re-echoing that the MOH/CDC CoAg does NOT and will NOT support services involving family planning, abortions, conferences, gender, diversity equity and inclusion (DEI), transgender surgeries or any other non-life saving services no listed under the PEPFAR limited waiver.

This activity is well aligned with the MoH mandate and award to provide support and strengthen the Ministry’s capacity to provide leadership to the National HIV/AIDS Response through coordination, policy development, mentorship and training under The United States President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). The teams will also troubleshoot site level challenges in service delivery and supply chain management. The planned activity will give a detailed report on gaps that may exist across the country regarding commodity availability and HIV service provision. This activity across health facilities is planned for the week beginning 5th May 2025. This activity will reinforce adherence to the PEPFAR waiver conditions which is a critical objective of this MoH Central Level Team visitations to subnational level activities. 

Key Deliverables

MoH needs to offer physical supervision to ascertain continuity of services and adherence to the PEPFAR waiver. While the PHOs and DHOs have already been visiting facilities to offer assessments and support, the MOH Central Team has not been present at f facility level since the stop work order. We are of the opinion that physical presence on the ground of the MOH Central Level Program Leadership will be critical to troubleshoot some of the persisting site level challenges in both HIV service provision and supply chain management. Further, the physical presence of MOH will help them have first-hand experience and understanding on what is obtaining on the ground following the stop work order, enforce adherence to the PEPFAR waiver, and redesign HIV service provision towards sustainability. This is in keeping with the oversight, monitoring and supervisory role of the MOH HIV Program supported by the MOH/CDC CoAg.  However, future assessment will be done by sub-national organs to ensure cost-effectiveness. 

Since this is the first full assessment after PEPFAR funding suspension:
	It will require a higher degree of involvement from MoH HQ to guide the process and ensure accuracy;
	MoH HQ will oversee the development of a clear and replicable assessment protocol that subnational teams can adapt for future iterations and easier onward roll out to other districts / facilities by Sub-National Level Teams.

The visitations or assessments will:
	Identify the optimal ratio of HQ and subnational involvement based on real-world data about current capacity, resource/commodities availability, and implementation challenges.
	Provide actionable insights into where HQ resources will be needed more and where subnational teams can take greater ownership.
	Enable data-driven decision-making to right-size the activity and allocate roles efficiently moving forward.

recipient_justification:
Name of Grantee: 	 	                                Western Provincial Health Office - WPHO 
 NOFO Number: 	                                        GH22-2206 
 Grant Cooperative Agreement Number: 	NU2GGH002441 
 Budget Period:                                           09/30/2024 - 09/29/2025 
 Date of Request: 	 	                                05/13/2025

 Spend Plan Drawdown Summary Request 	
 	 Approved Budget Category 	                                Summary Total of Request Amount (US$) 
1	Travel	                                                                                                                             9,005 
2	Supplies	                                                                                                                         3,904 
3  Other	                                                                                                                           29,955 
 	Total	                                                                                                                           42,864 

Activity Justifications

1.	SUPPORT TRAINING OF HF SMARTCARE CHAMPIONS IN SMARTCRE PRO
Enhances staff proficiency in SMARTCRE PRO, ensuring effective data management and system utilization. Well-trained champions can assist peers, improve reporting accuracy, and sustain system efficiency, ultimately strengthening health information systems and service delivery. 

2.	SUPPORT KAOMA SUPPORT SUPERVISORY VISITS FOR MER AND EDQIT
Improves monitoring of Medical Equipment Readiness (MER) and Emergency Data Quality Improvement Team (EDQIT) activities. Supervisory visits identify gaps, ensure compliance, and promote quality standards, leading to better resource management, data accuracy, and service delivery.

3.	SUPPORT MWANDI CONDUCT HVL IN PEADS MENTORSHIP
Mentorship in High-Volume Laboratories (HVL) enables the provision of high-quality pediatric care. The provision of hands-on support enhances testing accuracy, lab efficiency, and staff skills, thereby directly contributing to the early detection and management of pediatric health conditions.

4.	SUPPORT WPHO UNDERTAKE THE BIANNUAL TB/HIV REVIEW MEETING
The meeting facilitates a comprehensive assessment of TB/HIV programs, identifying progress and gaps. Results guide strategic planning, improve coordination, and optimize resource allocation, ultimately enhancing integrated disease control efforts and patient outcomes.

5.	SUPPORT WPHO CONDUCT VMMC SKILLS TRAINING FOLLOW UPS AND CERTIFICATION
The program ensures that healthcare workers maintain and update their circumcision skills through follow-ups and certification. Strengthening competency standards reduces complications, improves service quality, and promotes sustainable voluntary medical male circumcision programs.

6.	SUPPORT SESHEKE CONDUCT ASSET VERIFICATION EXERCISE
This exercise maintains accurate inventory records, prevents loss, and ensures proper utilization of equipment and supplies. Regular verification supports accountability, resource management, and operational efficiency in health facilities.

7.	SUPPORT WPHO CONDUCT TSS TO NEW SMARTCARE PRO SITES
Provides technical support to new sites adopting SMARTCARE PRO, facilitating smooth implementation. The team ensures proper system setup, staff training, and troubleshooting, which leads to seamless data management and improved health information workflows.

8.	SUPPORT SENANGA SERVICE AND REPAIR MOTORBIKES
The maintenance of motorbike fleet reliability is crucial for health outreach and logistics. Regular servicing reduces downtime, ensures timely service delivery, and enhances mobility for health workers operating in remote areas.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
Time frame for this drawdown is 4.12.2025 through 5.8.2025
The ITCM CRC Screening Project purpose includes the application of lessons 
learned from the multi-component Tribal Colon Cancer Collaborative Model (ITCM 2015-
2020): 1) partnerships with tribal health systems primary care clinics to implement at least 2
evidence based interventions (EBI) from The Community Guide; 2) partnerships with 
organizations which provide expertise in implementing EBIs in tribal clinics; 3) conducting an 
EBI readiness assessment; 4) Select suitable EBIs; 5) providing for follow up colonoscopies after 
a positive or abnormal screening test and 6) collecting high quality clinic –level data including 
baseline and annual CRC screening rates. 
This drawdown was for Salaries, fringe, operating expenses, and funding to participating tribes.

recipient_justification:
Dear PMS

Thanks for your feedback. Please find the information requested.

6 NU2GGH002176-05-06

Project Period: 04/01/2019 to 09/29/2024

Budget Period: 09/30/2023 to 09/29/2024

Reasons for request.

Please the reasons we are requesting this drawdown is to permit us to pay our audit report now due for the project period. We are the ministry of public health (MOH), and the audit procedures depend much on the MOH. We had some inevitable challenges which were independent of us. Therefore, these funds drawdown requests are meant to pay the outstanding audits for these periods that were not paid because they were not completed in its entirety. With the payments of all pending reports, it will permit us to submit the final reports as required and request for restrictions on our current budget. The amount requested will cover the pending audits from COP 18 to COP 23.

Thanks.

recipient_justification:
Clarification of Software Cost - $12,368.25

The software cost of $12,368.25, recorded under the current budget period 04/01/2024 – 03/31/2025, was initially included in anticipation of an approved budget revision. However, the budget amendment is still pending approval, and the amount does not currently align with the approved budget.

The intended cost pertains to TKO’s annual Jotform Enterprise subscription, which is used to support HIPAA-compliant:
	•	Data collection and management
	•	Data sharing and reporting
	•	Case management
	•	Client progress tracking

The total annual cost of the Jotform Enterprise subscription is $13,935.60. TKO is requesting 75% of the cost to be allocated to project activities, which equates to a revised request of $10,452.00 for this budget period.

TKO acknowledges the discrepancy and would like revise the payment request to reflect the appropriate allocation upon approval of the budget amendment.

agency_lead_justification:
When submitting your PMS drawdowns, please refrain from using the same justification for all payment entries. It is essential to provide sufficient justification for each requested amount. We also recommend itemizing the charges and including a summary for clarity. Following these guidelines will help ensure a smooth approval process for your PMS drawdowns by the CDC. Additionally, please specify the applicable timeframe, e.g., "These payments are for costs incurred in March 2025."

Examples: 
Payment Justification: Payroll and Fringe for Staff for March
Payment Justification: Subcontractor Payments to ABC Industries, DEFG Solutions
Payment Justification: Supplies for February-March– copies, paper
Payment Justification: Other – publications, insurance, professional services

recipient_justification:
Project Summary: Iasis Molecular Sciences Corporation (IMSC) has developed a new class of self-disinfecting materials that have been demonstrated to be highly effective against a variety of pathogens. The current award (2R44CK000621-02A1), Clinical Ecosystem Surfaces for Improved Disinfection Outcomes and the Prevention of HAI* Transmission (*healthcare-associated infection) is an applied research effort aimed at the commercialization of materials technology for surfaces (coatings and bulk materials that include touch surfaces, flooring, fabrics etc.) for use in clinical ecosystems, while noting that other environments (e.g., public transport) will also benefit from the surfaces described. HAIs are expensive to the healthcare system (~$40B annually), their occurrences divert important resources (nurses, doctors, funds), and the problem leads to 13,000 deaths annually. Implementing effective (passive) strategies to reduce the transmission of pathogens within the clinical ecosystem that can work synergistically with current disinfection practices is a logical approach to reduce the incidences of infections, lower healthcare costs, and save lives.

The reimbursement request of $ 23,165.15 is for the period 03/01/2025 – 03/31/2025. The reimbursement request breakdown is as follows:

Labor  $16,047.88 
Lab Supplies & Materials:  $549.81 
Items include (Water treatment chemicals, water treatment canisters for ion exchange, disposable microbiology supplies and reagents, storage & shipping containers, synthesis hardware, chemical reagents, test strips for purification methodology, incubator monitoring devices, and outsourced testing)
Indirect Expenses:  $6,567.46 
Overhead rate: 39.6%
All line items are within the guidelines of the approved budget for the period 09/30/24 - 09/29/25.

recipient_justification:
Time frame for this drawdown is 4.12.2025 through 5.8.2025. 
The ITCM Our Breath is Sacred; Three Fires Menthol and Flavored Tobacco Reduction Project 
will address upstream and downstream SDOH factors that influence the AI/AN and intersectional rural sub populations within the state of MI. ITCM will use community based 
participatory approaches to increase participation, engagement, and mobilization among diverse 
multi-level/multi-sector rural and urban community partners to implement evidence based 
interventions (EBI’s) that promote, educate and implement economic, and community policy 
changes regarding the sale and use of commercial menthol and other flavored commercial 
tobacco products. ITCM will assess TTA needs, deliver training on and support evidence based 
interventions and strategies, and monitor and evaluate outcomes. Funds are used to support salaries, fringe, site visit travel, and funding to the participating tribal communities.
