recipient_justification:
We are requesting a payment of $22,067.90 for the period of April 1, 2025-April 30, 2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $4320.36 Salary for Executive Director, provides oversight of the grant, including fiscal and personnel management, community relations and provides leadership. Associate Director oversees direct operations and supports and supervises community events, health fairs, school and parent programs. Project Coordinator, oversee the day-to-day operations including trainings, coalition communication, data collection and information dissemination. 
• Fringe Benefits: $461.56 Fringe benefits are reportable and taxable income federal and state tax laws, rules, regulations. • Travel: $138.60  Local travel is needed for staff to attend local meetings, project activities and training events and are set at current federal mileage rates. • Supplies: $241.35 - Office supplies including files, folders, ink, paperclips, pens, pencils are needed for administration of grant activities.  • Contractual/Subawards: $4925.00 Evaluation Contractor: monitors and evaluates the effectiveness of the Sumter CAP coalition and action plan, assist with data collection and analysis, assist with reporting to CDC, the Board, and community, monitor strategy outcomes, and provide TA on preparing reports for the community, organization. Will also assist with organizational development and capacity building, as well as implementation of sustainability plan and overall continuity of SPF process. Financial Management Assistance: tracks grant expenditures monthly, documenting grant-related activities, and making sure all expenses are properly classified. Financial manager has implemented efficient tracking and reporting system to ensure accuracy and compliance grant funding.
Graphic Design Specialist: updates, develops and enhance rack cards, brochures, worksheets and other literature as needed. This service is provided as needed to fulfill the workplan of the coalition.  Creative agency provides marketing services such as video production, post-production, social media and digital platform management and content optimization to saturate Sumter County with healthy substance abuse avoidance as well as enhance sustainability through attracting supports via digital platforms, such as Facebook, Instagram and Snapchat. 
Other: $11,981.03. Training Opportunities: CADCA MidYear registration fees to promote Coalition growth. Cell Phone: To reimburse cost for use of personal cell phone service: 
Electric: Utility fee for Sumter CAP office space provided through Sumter Electric Cooperative.  Insurance: DFC percentage of cost for liability and D&O insurance.  Friday Night Done Right (FNDR) Social Norming Campaign Materials.
Red Ribbon Week Event Materials: Materials will be used to support alcohol and drug free red ribbon week activities and promote awareness including Handouts,with Drug Avoidance messaging, Safe Disposal. Sumter CAP provides Deterra drug deactivation kits at Take Back Day and other community events. 
I certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.
NJ

The Immunization Program has 400 providers enrolled for distribution of vaccine to children and adults statewide to include underserved populations that are uninsured/underinsured and have limited acces to healthcare. It is necessary to provide these services as not adequately immunizing the population in the state may result in breakthrough disease, morbidity, and mortality. recipient_justification:
The purpose of the listing is to implement public health actions through engagement of national partners and public health networks at national, state and local levels to apply public health strategies to promote cognitive health; address cognitive impairment, including Alzheimer’s disease; and support the needs of care partners (paid and unpaid persons providing care or assistance to someone with Alzheimer’s disease or related dementia). This will be accomplished through the provision of technical assistance and support in the following areas: 1) Using data and information to develop, examine, and deploy effective strategies, identify and address gaps in implementation, create and assess technical assistance tools, and monitor progress in achieving program goals; 2) Engaging in environmental approaches that promote inclusion of cognitive health, cognitive impairment and caregiving into community and workplace policies and plans; 3) Supporting health system strategies to improve early detection of cognitive impairment, including Alzheimer’s disease, and increasing awareness among health care providers about care partner health and role in care management; and 4) Facilitating the translation and dissemination of information and resources through public health networks.

Line item 1 Dementia Caregiver Training $17,500, Line Item 2 Alzheimer's education brochures $2,500
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification:
The executive director's payroll is for April, and the evaluation services are from March to April.

The CADCA is a leadership conference held in Nashville from July 20 to July 24, Tennessee. We are excited to bring six Youth Wellness Council students to the Mid-Year Youth Leadership Institute. The conference aligns with our Action Plan and will educate students on prevention efforts in our community to reduce marijuana and alcohol use.  The Executive Director, Project Coordinator, and our Youth Coordinator are also attending. The Youth Coordinator will lead the students throughout the conference, and the ED and PC will attend the leadership track to gain prevention knowledge and be updated on the most current substance use trends. We are excited to participate in this conference and use carry-over money from Year 3, as we could not send any students to this fantastic conference last year. The requested money is paying for airfare and the conference itself.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval. 
NJ

3675	Miscellaneous	office supply		$38.10

	* Parent handbooks include info for talking to your children about all substances as well as social media and gaming and depression. 
** Youth Summit for 8th graders who are at special risk for not transitioning well to high school. Teaches them basic skills on how to avoid drug use, communicate with others, study skills who to go to for help and how to take care of their mental and physical health.

recipient_justification: This funding is from the Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control for Immunization and Vaccines for Children that supports vaccine preventable disease activities through staffing, contractual services, and supplies for maintaining vaccine distribution to all children and underserved adult populations. The Immunization Program has 400 providers enrolled for distribution of vaccine to children and adults statewide to include underserved populations that are uninsured/underinsured and have limited acces to healthcare. It is necessary to provide these services as not adequately immunizing the population in the state may result in breakthrough disease, morbidity, and mortality. By increasing access to immunizations, vaccine preventable diseases will decrease thus reducing the burden on the Health Care system. recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.
agency_lead_justification: CDC approves the requested drawdown in line with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, Subpart E—Cost Principles, and the HHSA Grants Policy Statement —Allowability of Costs/Activities. recipient_justification:
The Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Chippewa Indians Tribal Practices for Wellness in Indian Country project supports the implementation of tribal practices that build resiliency and connections to community, family, and culture, which over time can reduce risk factors for chronic disease among Sault Tribe members, families and community members. The long-term goals of the project are to increase resilience and use of cultural practices to reduce morbidity and mortality due to heart disease, stroke, cancer and diabetes, and increase mental and emotional wellbeing among community members.
Sault Tribe is implementing evidence-informed and culturally-adapted chronic disease prevention, management, and control strategies to improve the health of our community members and to prevent chronic diseases and their risk factors.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

3. Contractual - salary & fringe benefits were not used because the drug-free communities program in Gordon county, GA is in transition and does not have a project coordinator.  The program director has stepped in to take care of the day-to-day responsibilities of the coalition.  Other contractual work included graphic designer, website maintenance, social media content manager, external evaluators, who assist with program evaluation and outcome measures.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.
agency_lead_justification: CDC approves the requested drawdown in line with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, Subpart E—Cost Principles, and the HHSA Grants Policy Statement —Allowability of Costs/Activities. recipient_justification: These expenditures were incurred in accordance with the award terms and conditions for 24NU51CK000362JCVDC5.  The purpose of this core funding is to build and maintain capacity for detection, investigation and reporting of the relevant pathogens to inform prevention activities. Resources also enhance and strengthen case-based, laboratory-based, and outbreak surveillance for VPDs, respiratory viruses, and related conditions, allowing public health agencies to effectively collect and provide timely and complete surveillance data to inform public health action. The Enhanced VPD and Respiratory Virus Surveillance Program with the ELC Cooperative Agreement provides funding and technical support and builds on established epidemiology, laboratory, immunization, health information, and surveillance systems and capacities. In addition to VPD surveillance coordination, this section of the cooperative agreement focuses on respiratory virus surveillance and enhancing surveillance specifically for meningococcal disease, varicella, and acute flaccid myelitis.  See 5/01/2025 grant message for an expense category breakdown.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification:
Drawdown Request Clarification

Program Name:
Drug-Free Communities (DFC) Grant - Focus on Community

Time Period Covered by Payment Request:
March 1, 2025 – March 31, 2025

Summary of Approved Expenses and Activities:
The drawdown request covers payroll-related expenses associated with staff working on
the DFC Grant activities during March 2025. Specific activities include program
planning, youth engagement, coalition building, community education, and
administrative support to maintain and advance DFC program goals. See following
section for details and amounts.

Approved Budget Line Categories for Expenditures:
 Personnel: Staff salaries directly supporting DFC program initiatives, including
community education and youth leadership programming. March total $7,639.26.

 Fringe Benefits: Associated employer costs (e.g., payroll taxes, insurance
contributions) calculated based on gross wages. March total $1,329.00.

 Supplies: Physical program materials purchased. March expenses include
items bought for “Hidden in Plain Sight”, an event where participants try to find
illicit materials in a mock-up of a child’s room. March total $640.86

 Consulting and Contractual: Amounts paid for services rendered by outside
entities. March expense included fees paid to get a website running for our
coalition, which is a vital part of the Drug Free Communities program. Money
was also used to fund students at a local school who were giving presentations
on drugs and alcohol. March total $750.77.

 Other: Includes items that do not fit in the other categories. Includes insurance
and utilities. March total $745.89.

 Indirect cost: Federal de minimis cost rate. Program originally budgeted for
10% rate, before it was increased to 15%. March total $1327.03

Details from the Documentation:
 General Journal and Paycheck transactions processed throughout March 2025.
 Expenses are aligned with the approved budget categories for "Personnel"  and
"Fringe" costs as outlined in the grant.

 Payroll entries are supported by payment records from U.S. Bank Checking
Account, and each entry reflects the net amount disbursed for eligible personnel
costs.

Total Payment Request:
$12,432.81

Costs expended that are not allowable, allocable, and reasonable will result in disallowed costs and the funds will be recovered.

Program name: MiCRIA: Two-minute rapid assay platform for point-of-care diagnosis
Time period covered by payment request: 3/29/2025 - 4/12/2025

Approved budget per NoA:
Direct Labor including fringe: $126,631.00
Supplies: $25,208.00
Indirect including F&A, fee and TABA (Technical and Business Assistance): $94,411.00

Expenses charged in this period and justification:
Direct labor including fringe: $7,898.89 (Salaries for PI and 5 laboratory researchers on the team working directly on this project, based on number of hours committed to the project.  Fringe per  documented rate for 2024.)
Supplies including  pipetting reservoirs ($34.15), electrophoresis running buffers ($58.74), preventive maintenance for -80C freezer ($182.00), and Quality Assurance consulting time ($74.11) - total $349.00.  These are all supplies or services that are used directly in the laboratory to carry out this project, or to ensure compliance with quality assurance procedures that the laboratory is subject to.
Indirect cost: $3,744.73, comprising $2,960.17 F&A (at 35.89% of direct) + $784.56 fee (at 7% of total).  Rates are within SBIR guidelines and based on accounting documentation.

recipient_justification:
This payment was in the amount of $11,440.00 to the contracted vendor "Professional Data Analyses" for the billing period of 01/01/2025 to 03/31/25 for the evaluation of the Ohio WISEWOMAN Program. 

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s (CDC) Well-Integrated Screening and Evaluation for WOMEN Across the Nation (WISEWOMAN) program is at the forefront of the nation’s efforts to improve cardiovascular health for low-income, uninsured, and underinsured participants.
U.S. Congress authorized the WISEWOMAN program in 1993. The intent is to expand services to National Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program (NBCCEDP) participants aged 35-64 to address cardiovascular health concerns in a population made vulnerable through social determinants of health. There are currently 35 funded projects, 32 are states, one is a U.S. territory, and two are tribal organizations.
 
The Ohio WISEWOMAN Program is implemented through the Ohio Department of Health and commenced in 2023.  It is an enhancement to the Ohio Breast and Cervical Cancer Program (BCCP) and is offered to women who are enrolled in Ohio WISEWOMAN targeted geographic areas.

recipient_justification: Payroll is the first budget section on our approved budget narrative. We need staff to implement the services as written in the grant. We are now behind in payroll because of this process.  The additional $4000 was requested for the venue for our summer event. Our summer event is being hosted to address our 2 primary goals of the dfc-decrease youth substance use and capacity development. The forth of July is a high youth use time in our community. Additionally, it's a high safe risk time as people light off their own fireworks. We are holding the event to 1) give youth an activity to do instead of using substances and 2) give the community a place to congregate to watch the local fireworks instead of sitting off their own. We also be talking to community members to get them to join the coalition-hence build capacity.

GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification:
The MOH/CDC CoAg is the lead for maintaining HIV services including HIV treatment services, laboratory services, and monitoring & evaluation HIV services for People Living with HIV (PLWHIV) and Pregnant & Breast-Feeding Women (PBFW) as guided by PEPFAR waiver. In addition, to implement all aspects of the PEPAFR waiver, the MOH/CDC CoAg plays the monitoring role on how sites are providing the allowable services in conformity with the PEPFAR waiver. Further, the MOH/CDC CoAg ensures that HIV services are provided seamlessly and jointly between the Zambian Government and United States Government with mutual interest to serve the Zambian people. The National HIV Program also ensures that the well-meaning intentions of the PEPFAR waiver to safeguard the wellbeing of all people living with HIV, and pregnant and breastfeeding women who require prevention services is achieved. The high-level expertise in HIV treatment and prevention reside in this CoAg and these experts continue to provide direct service delivery in different health facilities in the country. 
Henceforth, The National HIV Treatment program has planned to procure various office supplies. These office supplies are essential, for the program, for efficient, effective and productive workplace outputs, both in clinical care and administrative. These various office supplies will enable smooth daily operations of the project office as well as technical staff providing oversight and leadership to the program, ultimately supporting effective and efficient service delivery aimed at contributing to reaching HIV epidemic control by 2030.

The MOH/CDC CoAg does NOT and will NOT support services involving family planning, abortions, conferences, gender, diversity equity and inclusion (DEI), transgender surgeries or any other non-life saving services no listed under the PEPFAR limited waiver.

Reason for payment request for March 1, 2025 through March 31, 2025

recipient_justification:
Notice of Funding Opportunity Number: GH-24-0058
Grant Number: 6NU66GH002181
Budget Period: 09/30/2024 - 09/29/2025
Reason for Payment Request:
This draw request includes payment for consultant compensation for work completed in April. The consultant coordinates with our local implementing partner, PAEI (Indonesian Epidemiological Association), US CDC Indonesia Office, and the health authorities in West Kalimantan, our subnational geography of focus. The majority of her work was in completion of a rapid assessment analysis and write-up along with planning for upcoming activities.

The costs in the Other category are associated with translation from Bahasa Indonesia into English transcripts from interviews and written surveys from the rapid assessment so that US CDC SMEs could review and advise.

The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period March 9, 2025, through March 22, 2025: Personnel $4,524.62, Fringe Benefits $1,402.63, and Indirect Costs $4,089.81 subtotal $10,017.06 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Liver Disease in the WTC General Responder Cohort.  It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the NOFO number PAR-20-280, 45 CFR Part 75 and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification: This grant will fund public health departments to build infrastructure in the field of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). recipient_justification:
This drawdown request is to reimburse the Town of Norwood for the salaries of the Program Director and Program Coordinator of the grade 6-12 drug use prevention program, IMPACT Norwood, during the time period of 4/1/25-4/30/25. During this period, the only expenses to be reimbursed are for the line item of ‘Personnel’ for both the full-time Program Director and part-time Program Coordinator, for a total of $8,899.98, as approved in the 2025 (Year 8) budget. The approved line item for Personnel for the Year 8 grant cycle are as follow:

Personnel: 

Federal Request: $97,084.26

These positions are essential to the successful implementation and ongoing management of the DFC grant activities and goals, including strategic planning, student-based meetings and leadership initiatives, outreach and events, program evaluation, and coordination of prevention and drug-free initiatives. Their efforts directly support the coalition’s goal to reduce drug use through data-based work, child and parental engagement and creating healthy activities for students in grades 6-12.

April 2025 approved action items, covered by this drawdown, include: 

Conduct a community forum to provide an update on coalition accomplishments, as well as review new data, strategic directions, and priorities; have high school students provide childcare, as needed. 

Maintain Youth Coalition by providing community service hours and development of Youth Leaders, Youth Driven media campaigns, events, and educational programs for peers.

Review data outcomes annually with the Steering Committee, Coalition and Town. 

Establish a mentorship program between high school youth coalition mentors and middle school students interested in becoming part of the coalition , including in-school prevention activities run by high school youth.

Emphasize the recruiting of parents with the goal of growing parental involvement by 25% each quarter.

Maintain social media presence with themed days of the week (mental health Monday, What’s Happening Wednesday, and Factual Friday).

Develop Press Releases when important developments are made on the coalition (i.e. Strategic Plan, new data, events, campaigns, etc.).

Attend as many Norwood events (minimum 2 per month) throughout the year (Norwood Day, Pre-Prom assemblies, PTO meetings, Athletic Events, etc.).

Develop Press Releases when important developments are made on the coalition (i.e. Strategic Plan, new data, events, campaigns, etc.).

Youth developed wellness campaigns – focused on community outreach including a “wellness magazine”, a senior center conversations program and public informational displays.

Partner with Mass General Hospital to provide a new program for students in grades 6-12 who are caught using substances within the schools.

Conduct an environmental scan to identify hot spots where youth drink alcohol/use marijuana. Determine if lighting, signage, security cameras or other physical design changes are an appropriate solution.

Regional Coalition Podcast for parents called “Where’s My Handbook?” to educate, inform and encourage parents of youth.

Free parenting workshops to assist parents in identifying drug-use in their children and provide resources to obtain necessary help, as needed.

Work with the School Committee and District Administration to help enhance teacher/staff response to student drug use.

 Enhance after school activities for students not participating in sports or other activities.

Attend events that parents are already going to, to provide information about youth substance use, mental health, etc. 

Provide opportunities for parents to engage with other parents and guardians in the town  to promote cross communication.

Update coalition and town about pending state and local alcohol/marijuana legislation.

recipient_justification:
The Drug Free Communities Grant is used to fund our prevention programs in the schools to educate teachers, social workers, Student Resource Officers and support staff on youth substance misuse trends, including underage vaping, alcohol and THC use. Our staff is in the school weekly educating students on vaping, THC, fentanyl, prescription drug misuse, impaired driving, binge drinking and illegal drug use. 
Drug Free Dickson was recently awarded Blue Ribbon Coalition status from CADCA, the first from the state of TN to receive this award and one of only a few nationwide. We recently had an independent cost benefit analysis conducted by Catalyst Evaluation Group and they determined “For every dollar invested in substance use prevention in Dickson County, Tennessee, a savings of $4.05 in public burden spending is realized.” We are very proud of the progress we are making in youth substance misuse prevention and would not be able to do it without funding from the DFC grant.
This month’s expenses support 3 staff implementing the programs in schools and our community. $7372.87 for staff, $884.98 benefits/taxes, $60 accounting fee for payroll services, $474.05 used to update our website with substance misuse resources for youth. For a total of $8791.90. Please let me know if you have any more questions, happy to answer them (:

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
All staff share responsibility for guiding the coalition in addressing priorities identified in the Action Plan and based upon the DFC Strategic Prevention Framework, maintaining focus on ‘best practices’ in environmental strategies, coalition volunteer capacity building, collecting and assessing needs assessment data effectively, and strengthening the viability of the Coalition.

The Project Director oversees administrative aspects of the project, provides supervision to staff, interfaces with the Fiscal Agent, community partners, and administrative entities, and oversees reporting as required by the Drug Free Communities Support Program.  Responsibilities include support of a comprehensive Communications Strategy, the dissemination of the Youth Mental Health First Aid training strategy, outreach to community partners and schools to increase capacity for comprehensive data collection in support of the policy development aspects of our strategic prevention framework, and of highest priority, working with sector representatives individually and collectively to continue development of the specific aspects of the Coalition’s sustainability plan.

The Coalition Coordinator strategically plans outreach to existing and prospective community partners, and facilitates the Coalition Work Groups to assist with: as well as coalition members and community officials.  The Coordinator works with the Director and Sector Leaders to develop evaluation reports and strategic planning based on data collected, and facilities Coalition workgroups developing identified strategies such as: community-level data collection including survey refinement and administration; development of materials and resources to inform and educate parents and other community members; social norms marketing (based on surveys and focus groups with parents); enhancement of coalition membership, and skills development within the coalition and the broader community.  The Coordinator will assist the Coalition in the development of additional resources that will promote the long-term sustainability of the Coalition and its efforts

The Youth Liaison/Communications Coordinator coordinates student-related prevention awareness activities and opportunities and provides information and reporting that assists the coalition in planning activities that correspond with school-based data and emerging issues, including the Above the Influence campaign and the Social Norms Marketing initiatives aimed at changing youth perceptions of peer use and supporting parent-teen communications around setting expectations that reduce the likelihood of teen use of targeted substances.

The Clerical/Fiscal Support Staff provides general clerical functions for the coalition, and maintains fiscal accounts, matching documentation, and report preparation for tracking of expenses.

List of expenses paid on behalf of programs supported for students and the communities:

Healthy Kids Day at the Y (Supplies and Time)
Glow in the Dark VolleyBall at WMS (Supplies & Time)
YRBS Parent mailing, Surveys and the work of CES analyzing the Data.(Envelopes, paper, postage)
Senior Class Signs 
Coalition Coordinator and Youth Liaison/Communications Coordinator participated in a virtual Stanford University conference.
Materials for MVP Awards
Travel expenses for  Coalition Coordinator and Youth Liaison/Communications Coordinator  for Coalition Promotional events
Upcoming...
"Michigan Model" / (Lifeskills) event
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval. 
NJ

To help expedite the approval process, please include the following information in your justification:
•Reason for Payment Request (e.g., salaries, contract or consultant invoices, supplies,travel, etc.) Please also include the timeframe for the drawdown.
When submitting your PMS drawdowns, please avoid using the same response for multiple payment justification entries. It is important to provide adequate justification; otherwise, your request may be rejected. We also recommend itemizing the charges and including a summary for clarity. Adhering to these guidelines will help ensure a smooth approval process for your PMS drawdowns by CDC. Examples: Payment Justification: Payroll and Fringe for Staff Payment Justification: Contractor/Consultant Payments to ABC Industries, DEFG Solutions Payment Justification: Supplies – copies, paperPayment Justification: Other – publications, insurance, professional services It’s recommended that you separate your payment request by awarding agency to prevent approval delays. If additional information is needed, the assigned GMS/GMO will contact you directly.

recipient_justification:
Pursuant to the award 5 NH28CE003049-05-00 dated July 28, 2024, of the total $74,000 allocated for personnel salaries, we hereby request the sum of $2847.00 to facilitate the biweekly remuneration of personnel. The Project Coordinator, Director, and Youth Coordinator are entrusted with oversight of the coalition's daily operations and activities in accordance with the approved action plan.  
Similarly, from the $31,250 allocated for contracts approved by the award, we are requesting $500 and $4,019.25 to settle contractors' invoices. SACED is the coalition grantee (fiscal agent) tasked with submitting the requisite program progress reports, the DFC Me annual coalition classification tool survey, and various financial reports. Additionally, SACED offers banking services, conducts bookkeeping, prepares payroll, disburses invoices, verifies DFC grant requirements and action plans, and provides all necessary administrative services. The fiscal agent furnishes office space, equipment, internet and phone services, utilities, and insurance. Grupo NEXOS, Inc. acts as the coalition's external evaluator.

recipient_justification:
Payment Request for CDC Grant NH28CE003798

We are requesting a payment of $7,237.14 for the period of March 1, 2025 to March 31, 2025.

The requested funds will be allocated as follows:

Personnel: $5,419.36 • Salaries for 1.1 personnel

Fringe Benefits: $929.42 • Based on 23% of direct salaries, includes payroll taxes and benefits

Supplies: $63.61 • Consumable office & program supplies

Other: $49.34 • Directly allocated cost of occupancy and program supports

Indirect Costs: $775.41 • Based on 12% of direct cost using approved Federal Indirect Cost Rate Agreement

These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: Coordination of HEY Randolph, a Drug Free Communities youth substance use prevention coalition and the HEY Randolph Youth Action Team. HEY Randolph Coalition is working on building community capacity to prevent alcohol and marijuana use, alcohol policy and compliance checks, youth leadership and advocacy, parent/caregiver education campaigns, and youth social norms campaigns.

recipient_justification:
The Ministry of Health (MoH) has continued to provide quality TB services across the country. To reduce TB related mortality, MoH through the National TB and Leprosy Program (NTLP) has continued scaling up use of TB Preventive Therapy (TPT) with over 90% coverage among PLHIV in the country. With short regimens included in the recent disseminated updated TPT guidelines, it was noted during the campaign that most facility staffs were not comfortable initiating patients on newer shorter regimens which are more efficacious and patient friendly.
 
The National Tuberculosis and Leprosy Program (NTLP) in collaboration with CDC Zambia will be supporting the Provinces to conduct targeted TPT technical support supervision and mentorship in selected Districts across the country. The main aim is to disseminate the TB Prevention guidelines and increase the use of short treatment regimen.
 
A total approved and concurred with amount of US$18,973.57 is being requested to be drawn down from PMS. These funds will support program and technical officers with travel expenses which include fuel and per diem (daily subsistence allowance) as per approved government rates. These funds will enable the central level teams comprising TB Program, Technical and Clinical Personnel travel to all the provinces, selected districts and facilities (Urban, Peri-Urban and Rural). This activity is well aligned with the MoH mandate and award to provide support and strengthen the Ministry’s capacity to provide leadership to the National TB and HIV/AIDS Response through coordination, policy development, mentorship and training under The United States President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).
 
This activity is aimed at improving uptake of TPT and increased usage of short regimen treatment and will be coupled with dissemination of the TPT guidelines in those districts where dissemination was not done by the provincial teams. The objective is to increase the TB prevention. The expected outputs of the activity include:-
 
• Dissemination of the updated TPT guidelines to health care workers Districts where the provinces did not finish;
• Increased initiation of TPT Shorter treatment regimens among eligible populations;
• Increased fidelity to implementation of TPT guidelines; and
• Improved reporting of the indicators related to the TPT guidelines.
 
The anticipated impact is the reduced mortality related to TB. Implementation of this activity will NOT support services involving family planning, abortions, conferences, gender, diversity equity and inclusion (DEI), transgender surgeries or any other non-life saving services no listed under the PEPFAR limited waiver.
agency_lead_justification: CDC approves the requested drawdown in the amount of $7,199.21 for approved training and travel expenses that align with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, Subpart E—Cost Principles, and the HHSA Grants Policy Statement —Allowability of Costs/Activities. Costs expended that are not allowable, allocable, and reasonable will result in disallowed costs and the funds will be recovered.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

•	Personnel - $3,271.63

•	Other - $185.79

These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: We are drawing down funds to support the WestCare GA Community Coalition in the implementation of key prevention strategies in the Mechanicsville -NPVU neighborhood communities, including mock DUI demonstrations, sticker shock and drug take-back events, at local school and community recreation center.  These efforts are part of our broader initiative to raise awareness around substance misuse and engage youth, families, and local partners. Funding is also used to provide materials, giveaways, and resources that amplify our message and ensure consistent community outreach across all programs. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice.

recipient_justification: MECASA is requesting reimbursement of March 2025 expenses for award # CDC-RFA-CE-24-0068. This award funds MECASA’s efforts to prevent sexual violence in Maine, with a focus on preventing the sexual abuse of children. The specific activities to achieve this goal include training and support for prevention staff at local sexual assault support centers across Maine; in March this included preparing for a webinar about students leading prevention activities in local high schools as well as revising evaluation surveys to assess the impact of current prevention education efforts. MECASA also provides training and support for community partners who are engaged in sexual violence prevention in Maine; in March this included work on curriculum about preventing sex trafficking of children. To ensure the success of these efforts, the coordination and support of MECASA’s Prevention Director are required daily. Approved budget categories aligning with the March reimbursement include salaries and fringe benefit, supplies, telephone / internet, technology and software, and insurance. Accordingly, the request for payment is based on the Prevention Director’s salary and benefits for the month of March 2025. These costs are calculated based on actual agency FTE effort on the project as reflected on daily timesheets. Also included are the associated program costs in line with the federal Uniform Guidance and DOJ Financial Guide and associated training.

recipient_justification:
Heartland Family Service is requesting a reimbursement for March 2025 Drug Free Communities Grant expenses incurred to further the efforts of the grant for the Pottawattamie County Drug Endangered Children Coalition (DEC).  This prevention coalition serves 15 communities and 8 school districts.  The overall goal of the grant and the DEC Coalition is to increase community collaboration and reduce substance use among youth in Pottawattamie County, Iowa.  

Labor $4330.84
Fringe Benefits $889.55
Supplies $31.46
Travel Costs $88.20
Other $177.21
Total Direct Costs $5,517.26
Indirect Cost $627.16
	We are requesting 1/12th of our approved indirect monthly to spread the reimbursement over the grant period.  Our indirect costs monthly exceed the available funds for reimbursement within this grant and we wanted federal funds to go farther for the Drug Endangered Children Coalition.
Total Reimbursement Request $6,144.42

We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award.

GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification:
The purpose of the Drug Free Communities (DFC) Grant is to support community collaboration among 12 sectors of representation to reduce substance misuse in youth.  The collaborative includes key stakeholders including health, schools, parents, business, law enforcement, faith community, civic, and others.

 

Increased capacity of collaborative partners to understand root causes of substance misuse in youth through training events.
Community Scan Training for collaborative members and staff to understand products accessible and appealing to youth.
Community Interview Training for collaborative members and staff  to learn how to do community interviews of neighbors, friends, and leaders to determine community attitudes about youth substance misuse.
Shared access for collaborative members to 4 Free Webinars on health effects of substance use.
Planning for Scans and Interviews in April.
Preparation and Planning for April Prescription Take Back Event at Medical Pavillion.
Parent Education Events to teach parents and teens refusal skills at 2 schools.
Home Safety Devices provided at each event.

Wages: $4,057.26
Fringe Benefits: $917.93
Training Expenses: $10.45
Indirect Cost: $488.24
agency_lead_justification:
GMO recommends payment approval.

recipient_justification: Grant award No.5 NU58DP007364-02-00 - Request payment to OmniTrak Group, Inc for contractual  services provided in April 2025 for continued support in collection for the Hawaii Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) for the service period from January 1, 2025, to June 29, 2025. The BRFSS is a critical public health surveillance initiative overseen by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Activities include the administration of CDC core questions, optional modules, and state-added items to capture timely, population-based data on health behaviors, chronic conditions, and preventive health practices among Hawaii residents. These data are essential for informing public health policy, program planning, and meeting federal reporting requirements. Ensuring timely and accurate data collection maintains the quality and integrity of the BRFSS dataset, which underpins evidence-based decision-making at the state, local, and national levels.

recipient_justification:
Grant award No.1U01DP006619-05-00- Request payment for payroll and fringe benefits for pay date 5/5/25, in the amount of $5,240 This position is approved in grant budget
This position provides access to the public on the health and wellbeing of mothers, not just babies before, during and after pregnancy and administer data collection to identify emerging health issues in the state on comprehensive information on mothers’ experiences.  I examine the data looking at the timing of prenatal care and barriers to postpartum care, to reduce infant mortality and increase postpartum checkups and other interactions with health care to organizations, health department, and various programs throughout the state.
We certify the payment is allowable, allocable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the NOA.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $1,401.11 on the DHHS – CDC grant number 5 R21 OH012623-02.  The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period March 9, 2025, through March 22, 2025: Personnel $632.87, Fringe Benefits $196.19, and Indirect Costs $572.05 subtotal $1,401.11 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Sleep stability, emotional memory, and risk for neurodegeneration in World Trade Center Responders. It has no component involving illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or assessing gender ideology issues and we certify that the costs are not used for such research activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with NOFO RFA-OH-23-001, 45 CFR Part 75 and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

This is a payment request for $5,109.35 on the DHHS – CDC grant number 5 R21 OH012623-02.  The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period April 6, 2025, through April 26, 2025: Personnel $2,307.85, Fringe Benefits $715.43, and Indirect Costs $2,086.07 subtotal $5,109.35for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Sleep stability, emotional memory, and risk for neurodegeneration in World Trade Center Responders. We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with NOFO RFA-OH-23-001, 45 CFR Part 75 and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu

Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

recipient_justification: Grant award No.6 NU50CK000553-04-05 - Request payment to Qiagen LLC for enhancing laboratory surveillance through the purchase of the QIAcuity OneStep Advanced Probe Kit is a justified use of COVID grant funds, as it directly supports improved detection and quantification of SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater samples. Wastewater surveillance is recognized as a cost-effective, community-level method to monitor infection trends and detect emerging variants, providing early warning for outbreaks and informing public health interventions. The QIAcuity kit, used with digital PCR systems, enables sensitive and accurate measurement of viral RNA in compliance with CDC guidelines for the National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS), strengthening laboratory capacity and surveillance infrastructure as required by grant activities. This aligns with the grant's objective to enhance laboratory and surveillance capabilities for effective COVID-19 response.  The funds are to be used for supplies ($5,096.59)

recipient_justification:
The payment requested is for Grant # 2 NH28CE002885-06-00.
We are requesting a payment of $4,713.03  for the timeframe of 4/7/25-4/21/25.
The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel $3,400.01; Fringe Benefits $314.02; Travel $0; Supplies $0; Other $999. 
Personnel and Fringe Benefit funds supported the Program Director, Project Coordinator, and Outreach Coordinator's work related to following grant activities from the 12-Month Action Plan (9/30/2024-9/29/2025): Attend community organization meetings to provide information on LEAD Phillipsburg, Enhance Skills of coalition by providing character building at monthly iLEAD meetings for youth to become Community change agents, Attend 10 local or county meetings related to youth substance use prevention and share Coalition efforts and vision; Provide coalition brochures containing data and strategies to combat youth substance use in both English and Spanish; Enhance skills by conducting training on data analysis for Coalition; Work related to the upcoming “Be My Parent Not My Bartender” Sticker Shock with Phillipsburg Police Department on the Thursday before Memorial Day Weekend; Host Middle & High School drop-in nights with diverse mentors, structured activities, and evidence-based prevention curriculums; Participate in National Prevention Week in May in the school district and at the Downtown Park; Participate in National Drugs and Alcohol Facts Week through print and media campaigns in the school district, community, and social media; Create and implement alcohol prevention campaign including billboards, yard signs, and flyers in support of National Alcohol Awareness Month in April; Extend evening youth alternative activity hours at the local recreation center for March Madness Championship Game; Utilize organization website with activities calendar for all prevention events and programs; Advocate for changes in school policy to include station house adjustment referrals and educational components; etc.

The "Other" category includes 3-months of designated office space for Coalition Staff, calculated at $333.00 per month and paid as per the Lease Agreement executed on July 1, 2019.

recipient_justification: These expenditures were incurred in accordance with the award terms and conditions for 19NU50CK000510NWS2C6.  The National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS) utilizes wastewater testing to understand disease prevalence trends in the community. NWSS partner sites coordinate with local partners, such as laboratories and wastewater utilities, to select sampling sites, facilitate laboratory testing, and submit data to the NWSS DCIPHER portal. Analyzed results are returned to partner sites to support public health action. In addition to community surveillance at wastewater treatment plants, NWSS partner sites conduct sub-sewer shed or targeted surveillance by sampling wastewater from facilities, institutions, or workplaces (e.g., nursing homes, universities, or correctional facilities). NWSS partner sites also engage with each of the other ELC recipients to support knowledge-sharing and accelerate the implementation and use of wastewater surveillance for public health action. NWSS partners may also conduct testing for additional pathogens, targets, and sequencing variants.  See 5/01/2025 grant message for an expense category breakdown.
agency_lead_justification: CDC approves the requested drawdown in line with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, Subpart E—Cost Principles, and the HHSA Grants Policy Statement —Allowability of Costs/Activities. recipient_justification:
Safe Yakima Valley's DFC grant is structured in direct response to what our local data has shown is our most pressing youth substance misuse concerns - alcohol, tobacco, marijuana, and prescription pills. Safe Yakima Valley focuses on youth substance use PREVENTION - only 3% of federal funds are currently being used for youth prevention efforts while 97% is spent on treatment and recovery. Yet, data shows that prevention is the MOST EFFECTIVE way to reduce youth substance use. In fact, DFC coalitions have reduced youth substance use across all substances by more than 30% since DFC's inception using evidenced-based strategies. Every dollar invested in prevention saves communities $18 in treatment/recovery expenses. Why? Prevention focuses on changes attitudes and behaviors of POPULATIONS. Treatment and recovery are individualized. Prevention costs an average of $263 per person; treatment/recovery costs $6-7 million per person. Addiction is an adolescent disease - over 90% of adults who struggle with substance use disorder indicate they started using substances as a youth. Additionally, youth in rural communities exhibit higher rates of substance use and co-occurring substance use disorders. Prevention is critical to curbing substance use and reducing the effects of the opioid epidemic.
Safe Yakima Valley serves as a Yakima County-wide convening organization tasked with building strategic partnerships, facilitating collaborative planning efforts, and coordinating resources to measurably reduce drug availability/accessibility and drug-related crimes in our community. Safe Yakima Valley works with local law enforcement agencies, first responders, the DEA, local schools, treatment providers, the Wa St Liquor & Cannabis Control Board, and other community members to develop and disseminate effective prevention strategies and activities for youth and community audiences to increase awareness about the harms of youth substance use while simultaneously teaching youth general life skills and drug resistance skills. 
Youth who start their initial substance (typically tobacco, 	alcohol, or marijuana) on or before age 14 have a 34% 	chance of developing a long-term substance use disorder.	If through prevention work, we can delay the initial onset to age 15, the risk drops 5%; if we delay the initial onset until age 16, it drops another 5%; if a child waits until age 18 to try that first sip of alcohol, 	puff of a cigarette, they are unlikely to ever develop a 	long-term SUD. Our evidenced-based prevention efforts teach youth lifeskills and positive social norms; we teach parents the risks of substances and the importance their role plays in prevention (parents are the #1 protective factor). We expose youth to protective factors to offset the risk factors in their lives that may lead them to substance use. 
The current draw is requesting $3,611.81 to cover salaries/fringe for 1.2 FTE as well as 15% deminimus to cover part of our indirect expenses for the month. The majority of our grant funds personnel/fringe. Future draws may request monies for our contract evaluator (to measure the effectiveness of our programs) or general supplies.

recipient_justification:
NACA thru TPWIC seeks to reduce illness and death from chronic diseases in American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) communities by promoting wellness, resilience, and use of cultural practices that strengthen community, family, and cultural connections. Support physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual health and improve well-being within AI/AN communities. Six strategies include Family and community activities: Programs that connect cultural teachings with health and wellness. Seasonal practices: Cultural traditions that promote health throughout the year. Community wellness: Social and cultural activities that improve the health of communities. Intergenerational learning: Opportunities for sharing knowledge between generations to build resilience. Healthy eating: Teachings about and use of traditional healthy foods to promote health, nutrition, and sustainability. Physical activities: Traditional and contemporary physical activities that strengthen well-being.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification: These expenditures were incurred in accordance with the award terms and conditions for 19NU50CK000510SHP2C6. These funds are broadly intended to provide critical resources to state, local, and territorial health departments in support of a broad range of healthcare infection prevention and control (IPC) activities and epidemiologic surveillance related activities to detect, monitor, mitigate, and prevent the spread of SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 in healthcare settings. These funds may also reasonably address other conditions in healthcare settings, such as healthcare associated infections (HAIs) and antimicrobial resistance (AR), which rely upon the same fundamental IPC and epidemiologic surveillance approaches that are used to detect, monitor, mitigate, and prevent the spread of SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 in healthcare settings. Moreover, the prevention of AR pathogens and improving the appropriate use of antibiotics helps to protect COVID patients from complications and potential comorbidities. Additionally, recipients should leverage and build upon existing ELC infrastructure that emphasizes the coordination and critical integration of laboratory with epidemiology and health information systems in order to maximize the public health impact of available resources.  See 5/01/2025 grant message for an expense category breakdown.

recipient_justification:
Personnel: $24,803.50
Personnel covers the cost of two staff members; our Tribal Opioid Response counselor, who provides direct services to clients with Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) as part of our Behavioral Health program, and our Recovery Works!/TIWA Time Coordinator, who provides group counseling, peer mentoring, and pain reduction/Opioid Use Prevention services for Community
Fringe $5441.83
Fringe is typically calculated at a 30% estimate depending on the benefits that an employee(s) chooses to utilize. 
Travel: $454.48 
This line item covered airfare for a client to treatment out of State for OUD. Client needed a higher level of care than was available in our State, so the TOR program facilitated access to inpatient treatment at the higher level of care.
Materials $473.80
Staff purchased a tablet for use in the field (home visits, jail, out of office visits)
Janitorial Supplies-$242.97
Self explanatory, but needed to keep client and staff spaces clean and sanitary.
R/M Building 855.13
Office space had a broken window when staff moved in to new building space. Funds were spent to replace window for safety.
Utilities $9906.03
Self explanatory, but covers water/sewer, and gas (heat).
Telephone 80.90
Cell phone for staff
Community Activities: 8520.00
Providers come to the TOR program office and provide non-pharmaceutical pain relief for all community members, in order to assist with prevention of the prescription of Opioid pain killers, or to assist OUD clients who may be in withdrawals from Opioid use. Managing pain without the use of pharmaceuticals helps with unnecessary prescriptions for pain killers.
Indirect cost: 12702.25 
Indirect provides Accounting functions. Payroll, HR, Facilities and IT services.

We are requesting a payment of $3,589.62 for the period April 24, 2025, through May 9, 2025. The requested funds will be used to support the following activities outlined in the Notice of Award (NOA):

Grant Coordinator/Director: $60
Administrative Assistant: $60
Financial Assistant: $60
These expenditures are essential to maintaining effective project implementation, monitoring, and communication, in accordance with the objectives of the grant.

recipient_justification: Grant award No.5 NU58DP007452-02-00 - Request payment to OmniTrak Group, Inc for contractual  services provided in April 2025 for continued support in collection for the Hawaii Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) for the service period from January 1, 2025, to June 29, 2025. The BRFSS is a critical public health surveillance initiative overseen by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Activities include the administration of CDC core questions, optional modules, and state-added items to capture timely, population-based data on health behaviors, chronic conditions, and preventive health practices among Hawaii residents. These data are essential for informing public health policy, program planning, and meeting federal reporting requirements. Ensuring timely and accurate data collection maintains the quality and integrity of the BRFSS dataset, which underpins evidence-based decision-making at the state, local, and national levels.

recipient_justification:
Are you kidding me? Fine. This is a Drug Free Communities grant award. Also known as DFC. In the award there is detailed information regarding exactly what the funds are to be used for. In this draw, the award clearly includes payroll for three positions. Specifically, one full-time position and two part-time positions. The total payroll requirement of those three positions is $3,262.95 every two weeks. There are also payroll processing costs as we use a payroll service of $145 per month due in the first of the month. Then a couple of supplies and postage for the $77.61 balance.

Don't get me wrong. I totally support the effort of identifying fraud and abuse in the Federal Grant system. In fact, I applaud the effort. But, this type of approach is concerning and questionable. It is as if you are asking me to do the job you were paid to do. If you actually researched the award that you are asking me to provide detailed information on, you would have already clearly seen that the award includes three positions and therefore require funds for payroll. If you require detailed information for some pens and pencils and $73 for postage, then so be it. It just seems ridiculous and petty to ask folks like me to spend our time providing this information on basically, milk money. If it is determined that these DFC awards are to terminated and no longer funded, then make the decision, communicate the decision and move on to the next thing. But, there is no reason to ask for detailed information every time a request for allocated, approved and budgeted award amounts are requested. In my humble opinion, however this justification was determined, there was no due diligence or research conducted.

recipient_justification:
DFC Grant # NH28CE003832.
This request is for: 
- Salaires/Fringe: Payroll for 4/7/25-4/20/25. Justification:  Run DFC coalition programming and aligns with the Trump Administration’s Drug Policy Priorities, including: Reduce the Number of Overdose Fatalities, with a Focus on Fentanyl, and Prevent Drug Use Before It Starts.
- Travel: Mileage to pick up student art and event supplies for a Youth Art Competition (April 16, 2025). Justification: The art competition is one of our DFC program activities, where students create art promoting a drug- and alcohol-free lifestyle. This aligns with DFC priorities to create diversion activities and public awareness of drugs like fentanyl. This also aligns with the Trump administration’s drug policy priorities stated above. 
- Other: Posters for youth art competition (04/22/2025). Justification: The art competition is one of our DFC program activities, where students create art promoting a drug- and alcohol-free lifestyle. This aligns with DFC priorities to create diversion activities and public awareness of drugs like fentanyl. This also aligns with the Trump administration’s drug policy priorities. 
- Other: April monthly office parking permit for program manager (04/22/2025). Justification: Program manager runs DFC coalition programming and aligns with the Trump Administration’s Drug Policy Priorities, including: Reduce the Number of Overdose Fatalities, with a Focus on Fentanyl, and Prevent Drug Use Before It Starts.

recipient_justification:
The Rape Prevention and Education Grant FAIN 24NUF2CE002580 has a primary purpose which is to prevent sexual violence perpetration and victimization. This is achieved through the Louisiana Foundation Against Sexual Assault (LaFASA), the state’s sexual violence coalition. The LaFASA funds 13 sexual assault centers to conduct legislatively approved activities. BFH contracts with LaFASA to provide training and technical assistance to sexual assault centers and stakeholders, and to monitor the sexual assault centers’ performance in activities and evaluation. The LaFASA contracts with the sexual assault centers to provide prevention and intervention services to their local communities, and conduct evaluation of their services.

These funds were utilized for payroll and related benefits as well as procurement of computers/laptops for program staff from the grant awarded 2/01/2025. These expenses are necessary to meet the grant’s required deliverables

recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $2,934.64 on the DHHS – CDC grant number 1 R21OH012790-01-00.  The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period March 9, 2025, through March 22, 2025: Personnel $1,325.55, Fringe Benefits $410.92, and Indirect Costs $1,198.17 subtotal $2,934.64 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Comprehensive Self-Management Support for WTC Responders with Asthma.  It has no component involving illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or assessing gender ideology issues and we certify that the costs are not used for such research activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with NOFO RFA-OH-24-002, 45 CFR Part 75 and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

recipient_justification:
Hello:  Here is the breakdown for this drawdown in 2 sections 
Salary & Contractual Costs:    (1) Payroll total:  $2,701.24 for Pay period:  4-13-25 through 2-26-25 broken down as follows:  Project Director (PD):  $433.45 - The Project Director will provide daily oversight of the grant. This position is responsible for overseeing the implementation of the project activities, internal and external coordination, developing materials, and conducting meetings.
Project Coordinator (PC):  $2,267.79 will coordinate project service and activities, including training, communication, and information dissemination, he is also responsible for the facilitation of youth, parent, and adult engagement in coalition efforts and coordination of special projects, and the production of financial reports.
(2) Contracts:  $2,500.00 - Installment on  Contractual Costs for Evaluation 
Justification for Contractual Cost
Epiphany Community Service (ECS) will serve as the evaluator for the entire duration of the five-year contract period. The evaluator's role is crucial for ensuring the effectiveness and efficiency of our program. ECS will provide the following services:
Prevention Technical Assistance and Training: ECS will offer specialized training and assistance to our staff and stakeholders to improve prevention strategies and methodologies.
Process and Outcomes Evaluation: ECS will conduct thorough evaluations of both the processes and outcomes of our program. This will help in assessing the program's impact and identifying areas for improvement.
Surveys Design and Review: ECS will help design and review surveys to collect data that will inform our program's direction and effectiveness.
The evaluator's tasks will be overseen and approved by the Executive Director to ensure alignment with our program objectives and goals.
Rationale for Selection: Epiphany Community Service was selected for this contract due to their extensive experience and proven track record in providing high-quality evaluation services. Their expertise in prevention technical assistance, training, and evaluation makes them uniquely qualified to support our program. The decision to contract with ECS is based on their ability to deliver specialized services that meet our program's needs and their history of successful collaborations with similar organizations.
Period of Performance: The contract with ECS will cover the entire five-year period of our program, ensuring continuity and consistency in evaluation services.
Method of Accountability: The performance and progress of ECS will be monitored through regular reports and evaluations coordinated by the Executive Director. This oversight will ensure that the services provided meet our standards and contribute to the achievement of our program objectives.
Respectfully submitted, Lori - 5167240551

recipient_justification: Y24149 BP 09/30/2024-09/29/2025 Patient Services for Family Planning Services of Snyder, Union & Northumberland Co from 2/1 - 2/28 2025 to offer eligible women participation in approved cardiovascular disease (CVD) improvement programs including health coaching (HC) or lifestyle programs (LSP). Prior to HC/LSP, the provider must obtain the health history, conduct medical screening including prescriptions for medications medically necessary, and conduct risk reduction counseling. Social service resource referral (SSRR) needs are to be assessed, referrals made, and follow-up documented.  These services are offered to clients ages 35-64 years old, who are uninsured, underinsured, below 250% of poverty and meet the eligibility for the free breast and cervical cancer program. Specific activities shall include: CVD screening, risk reduction counseling, SSRR, and LSP/HC to eligible participants.

recipient_justification: Award No: 6 NH28CE003424-03-01 According to 2 CFR 200.414(f) "Recipients and subrecipients that do not have a current Federal negotiated indirect cost rate (including provisional rate) may elect to charge a de minimis rate of up to 15 percent of modified total direct costs (MTDC). The recipient or subrecipient is authorized to determine the appropriate rate up to this limit." Redington Fairview General Hospital, as the recipient of this award, has elected to use 10% to cover the cost of its indirect costs (general and administrative costs). Also stated in 2 CFR 200.414(f), "the de minimis rate does not require documentation to justify its use and may be used indefinitely."  MTDC for this was $9,206.44 from the following expense lines; Salaries $5,210.41, Fringe Benefits $2,325.41, Supplies $1,596.00, Travel $74.62. As such, 10% of MTDC equals $920.64 which is what was submitted for payment. Expenses were incurred during the timeframe of 3/1/2025 to 3/31/2025.
agency_lead_justification: CDC approves the requested drawdown in line with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, Subpart E—Cost Principles, and the HHSA Grants Policy Statement —Allowability of Costs/Activities. recipient_justification:
Name of Grantee: 		 Western Provincial Health Office - WPHO 
 NOFO Number: 		 GH22-2206 
 Grant Cooperative Agreement Number: 		 NU2GGH002441 
 Budget Period: 09/30/2024 - 09/29/2025 
Reason for payment Request: Travel
Spend Plan: Travel - $818.96 
Justification:
Limulunga Maternal Retesting Above Site Mentorship and Technical Support to HFs
Funds will be used for maternal retesting mentorship and technical support services for HIV-positive pregnant mothers to enhance improved health outcomes, as regular HIV retesting for pregnant women is crucial for early detection and treatment. This can significantly reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV, improving both maternal and infant health outcomes. The above site will also enhance capacity building, which will help healthcare workers develop the necessary skills and knowledge to manage HIV testing, counseling, and treatment effectively. Such development can lead to more competent health care providers who are better equipped to handle HIV cases. Supporting maternal HIV retesting promotes the integration of HIV services into maternal health care. This holistic approach ensures that women receive comprehensive care, addressing both their pregnancy needs and HIV management.
agency_lead_justification: CDC approves the requested drawdown in line with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, Subpart E—Cost Principles, and the HHSA Grants Policy Statement —Allowability of Costs/Activities. Costs expended that are not allowable, allocable, and reasonable will result in disallowed costs and the funds will be recovered.
